The sermon was about brotherly love, and everybody listened real close, but I couldn’t help but notice that the Grangerfords and the Shepherdsons was sitting on opposite sides of the church, and they kept looking at each other like they was just waiting for something to happen. It seemed kind of strange to me, but nobody else seemed to think anything of it.

Miss Sophia asked me to go over to the church and get her Testament for her. She said she’d left it in her pew, and she wanted it right away. I didn’t think anything of it, so I went and got it for her. When I opened it, I found a note inside. I didn’t read it, but I could tell it was important. I gave it to Miss Sophia, and she looked real happy and thanked me. I didn’t know what was going on, but I had a feeling it was something secret.

events.title: Introduction of the Shepherdson Feud and Buck's Ambush of Harney
detailed_summary: Huck learns about another prominent local aristocratic family, the Shepherdsons, who are described as equally high-toned, well-born, wealthy, and grand as the Grangerfords.

The Shepherdsons and Grangerfords used the same steamboat landing, located about two miles from the Grangerford house, where Huck sometimes saw Shepherdsons on their fine horses when accompanying the Grangerfords.
One day, while Huck and Buck are hunting in the woods, they hear a horse approaching as they cross a road.
Buck urgently tells Huck to hide in the woods. They do so and observe a splendid young man, Harney Shepherdson, galloping by, whom Huck had seen before.
Buck fires his gun at Harney, causing Harney's hat to fall off. Harney grabs his own gun and rides towards their hiding spot.
Huck and Buck flee through the woods. Huck looks back and twice sees Harney aiming his gun at Buck before Harney rides away, presumably to retrieve his hat.

They run all the way home. Colonel Grangerford's eyes initially show a hint of pleasure but then he gently expresses disapproval of shooting from an ambush, asking Buck why he didn't step into the road.
Buck defends his action by stating that the Shepherdsons always resort to taking unfair advantages.
Miss Charlotte reacts to Buck's account with queenly pride, her nostrils flaring and eyes snapping. The two young Grangerford men look grim but say nothing.
Miss Sophia turns pale upon hearing of the incident but her color returns when she learns Harney was not injured.

events.text_segment:
There was another clan of aristocracy around there—five or six families—mostly of the name of Shepherdson. They was as high-toned and well born and rich and grand as the tribe of Grangerfords. The Shepherdsons and Grangerfords used the same steamboat landing, which was about two mile above our house; so sometimes when I went up there with a lot of our folks I used to see a lot of the Shepherdsons there on their fine horses.
One day Buck and me was away out in the woods hunting, and heard a horse coming. We was crossing the road. Buck says:
“Quick! Jump for the woods!”
We done it, and then peeped down the woods through the leaves. Pretty soon a splendid young man come galloping down the road, setting his horse easy and looking like a soldier. He had his gun across his pommel. I had seen him before. It was young Harney Shepherdson. I heard Buck’s gun go off at my ear, and Harney’s hat tumbled off from his head. He grabbed his gun and rode straight to the place where we was hid. But we didn’t wait. We started through the woods on a run. The woods warn’t thick, so I looked over my shoulder to dodge the bullet, and twice I seen Harney cover Buck with his gun; and then he rode away the way he come—to get his hat, I reckon, but I couldn’t see. We never stopped running till we got home. The old gentleman’s eyes blazed a minute—’twas pleasure, mainly, I judged—then his face sort of smoothed down, and he says, kind of gentle:
“I don’t like that shooting from behind a bush. Why didn’t you step into the road, my boy?”
“The Shepherdsons don’t, father. They always take advantage.”
Miss Charlotte she held her head up like a queen while Buck was telling his tale, and her nostrils spread and her eyes snapped. The two young men looked dark, but never said nothing. Miss Sophia she turned pale, but the color come back when she found the man warn’t hurt.

But they never did anything at church, except look at one another, and it was always so full of people that there wasn’t any chance for anything to happen.

The Shepherdsons were proud and grand, and they had fine houses and plantations, and many slaves, just like the Grangerfords. Their young men were brave and gallant, and their young women were beautiful and high-spirited. The feud between the two families was so old that nobody could remember how it started, but it was kept alive by pride and honor, and by the blood that had been shed on both sides. Every now and then, somebody would get killed, and then there would be more trouble, and more killing, and the feud would go on.

I got to know some of the Shepherdsons, and they were mighty nice folks, too. It seemed a pity that such good people should be enemies, and that they should be always watching for a chance to hurt one another. I used to wonder what would happen if the families could just forget the old quarrel and be friends, but I reckoned that was too much to hope for.

events.title: Buck's Explanation of the Generations-Long Feud
detailed_summary: Once alone with Buck, Huck asks if he truly intended to kill Harney Shepherdson, and Buck affirms he did.
When Huck questions why, given Harney had done nothing to Buck personally, Buck explains it is because of the feud between their families.

Huck, unfamiliar with feuds, prompts Buck to explain. Buck describes a feud as a cycle: a man quarrels with another and kills him, then the victim's brother kills the killer, followed by retaliation from other brothers and cousins on both sides, continuing until everyone is dead, a process he notes is slow and lengthy.
Buck reveals that this particular feud has been ongoing for about thirty years, originating from some trouble and a subsequent lawsuit, after which the loser of the suit shot the winner.
He admits he doesn't know the original cause of the dispute, possibly land, and that even the older generation, like his father, no longer recalls the initial reason for the conflict.
Buck confirms many have been killed over the years, with numerous funerals. He mentions his father has buckshot in him, Bob has been cut with a bowie knife, and Tom has been injured.

He recounts a recent event where his fourteen-year-old cousin, Bud, unarmed and foolishly trying to outrun old Baldy Shepherdson, was shot and killed. Within a week, the Grangerfords retaliated and killed Baldy.

Huck suggests old Baldy Shepherdson was a coward, but Buck vehemently refutes this, stating there are no cowards among the Shepherdsons or the Grangerfords. He illustrates this by recounting a fight where Baldy, though outnumbered by three mounted Grangerfords, fought bravely from behind a woodpile, resulting in his own and his horse's injuries but also the death of two Grangerfords.

Soon as I could get Buck down by the corn-cribs under the trees by ourselves, I says:
“Did you want to kill him, Buck?”
“Well, I bet I did.”
“What did he do to you?”
“Him? He never done nothing to me.”
“Well, then, what did you want to kill him for?”
“Why, nothing—only it’s on account of the feud.”
“What’s a feud?”
“Why, where was you raised? Don’t you know what a feud is?”
“Never heard of it before—tell me about it.”
“Well,” says Buck, “a feud is this way. A man has a quarrel with another man, and kills him; then that other man’s brother kills him; then the other brothers, on both sides, goes for one another; then the cousins chip in—and by-and-by everybody’s killed off, and there ain’t no more feud. But it’s kind of slow, and takes a long time.”
“Has this one been going on long, Buck?”
“Well, I should reckon! It started thirty year ago, or som’ers along there. There was trouble ’bout something, and then a lawsuit to settle it; and the suit went agin one of the men, and so he up and shot the man that won the suit—which he would naturally do, of course. Anybody would.”
“What was the trouble about, Buck?—land?”
“I reckon maybe—I don’t know.”
“Well, who done the shooting? Was it a Grangerford or a Shepherdson?”
“Laws, how do I know? It was so long ago.”
“Don’t anybody know?”
“Oh, yes, pa knows, I reckon, and some of the other old people; but they don’t know now what the row was about in the first place.”
“Has there been many killed, Buck?”
“Yes; right smart chance of funerals. But they don’t always kill. Pa’s got a few buckshot in him; but he don’t mind it ’cuz he don’t weigh much, anyway. Bob’s been carved up some with a bowie, and Tom’s been hurt once or twice.”
“Has anybody been killed this year, Buck?”
“Yes; we got one and they got one. ’Bout three months ago my cousin Bud, fourteen year old, was riding through the woods on t’other side of the river, and didn’t have no weapon with him, which was blame’ foolishness, and in a lonesome place he hears a horse a-coming behind him, and sees old Baldy Shepherdson a-linkin’ after him with his gun in his hand and his white hair a-flying in the wind; and ’stead of jumping off and taking to the brush, Bud ’lowed he could out-run him; so they had it, nip and tuck, for five mile or more, the old man a-gaining all the time; so at last Bud seen it warn’t any use, so he stopped and faced around so as to have the bullet holes in front, you know, and the old man he rode up and shot him down. But he didn’t git much chance to enjoy his luck, for inside of a week our folks laid him out.”
“I reckon that old man was a coward, Buck.”
“I reckon he warn’t a coward. Not by a blame’ sight. There ain’t a coward amongst them Shepherdsons—not a one. And there ain’t no cowards amongst the Grangerfords either. Why, that old man kep’ up his end in a fight one day for half an hour against three Grangerfords, and come out winner. They was all a-horseback; he lit off of his horse and got behind a little woodpile, and kep’ his horse before him to stop the bullets; but the Grangerfords stayed on their horses and capered around the old man, and peppered away at him, and he peppered away at them. Him and his horse both went home pretty leaky and crippled, but the Grangerfords had to be fetched home—and one of ’em was dead, and another died the next day. No, sir; if a body’s out hunting for cowards he don’t want to fool away any time amongst them Shepherdsons, becuz they don’t breed any of that kind.”

I asked him what started it, but he said he didn't rightly know. "Pa says it was something about a horse, a long time ago. But now it's just because it's always been."

I thought that was mighty strange, but I didn't say nothing. I just listened, and Buck told me about how sometimes the Shepherdsons would shoot at them if they met in the woods, and how the Grangerfords would do the same. He said it was dangerous, but he wasn't scared. "It's just the way things is," he said.

We sat there a while, listening to the birds and the wind in the trees. I felt kind of lonesome, thinking about Jim and the raft, and wondering if I'd ever see him again. But Buck was good company, and I liked him.

After a bit, Buck said, "Come on, Huck, let's go down to the river. Maybe we can see some fish."

So we went, and we spent the afternoon throwing rocks in the water and talking about all sorts of things. Buck told me about his family, and I told him about the adventures I'd had with Tom and Jim. He liked hearing about the raft, and said he wished he could go floating down the river, too.

When it started to get dark, we headed back to the house. The Grangerfords were all sitting on the porch, talking and laughing. They asked us where we'd been, and Buck said we'd been down by the river. Nobody seemed to mind.

That night, I lay in bed thinking about the feud, and about how folks could hate each other for so long and not even remember why. It didn't make much sense to me, but I reckoned it wasn't my place to say.

The next morning, Buck woke me up early. "Come on, Huck," he said. "Let's go hunting."

We got our guns and headed out into the woods. It was quiet and cool, and the sun was just coming up. We didn't see any deer, but we saw some rabbits and squirrels. Buck was a good shot, and he showed me how to track animals by looking at their footprints.

After a while, we sat down on a log to rest. Buck looked at me and said, "Huck, do you ever get scared?"

I thought about it. "Sometimes," I said. "But mostly I just try to keep out of trouble."

Buck nodded. "Me too. But Pa says a Grangerford ain't supposed to be scared of nothing."

I didn't say nothing to that. I just looked out at the trees and thought about how different folks was, and how sometimes it didn't matter if you was scared or not, you just had to keep going.

events.title: Ironic Church Sermon and Miss Sophia's Mysterious Errand
detailed_summary: The following Sunday, both the Grangerford and Shepherdson families attend church, with all the men from both clans carrying their guns and keeping them readily accessible during the service.

The sermon delivered is ironically about brotherly love and other religious themes, which Huck finds tiresome. However, the congregation, including the feuding families, deems it a good sermon and discusses it extensively on their way home.
Later that afternoon, while the household is dozing, Miss Sophia approaches Huck in the hallway.
She asks Huck if he likes her and if he would be willing to do something for her secretly, to which he agrees.
Miss Sophia explains she forgot her Testament at church, between two other books in the pew, and asks Huck to quietly go fetch it for her, stressing that he tell no one.
Huck complies, finding the church empty except for a few hogs seeking coolness on the puncheon floor. He notes that hogs seem more regular churchgoers than people.
Feeling that Miss Sophia's agitation about a Testament is unnatural, Huck shakes the book, and a small piece of paper falls out with "Half-past two" written on it in pencil.
He can't decipher its meaning, so he puts the paper back in the Testament and returns to the Grangerford house.
Miss Sophia is waiting for him, pulls him into her room, finds the paper in the Testament, and looks immensely pleased upon reading it.
She then impulsively hugs Huck, calls him the best boy in the world, and reiterates that he must not tell anyone. Her face is flushed, and her eyes are bright, making her look very pretty.

When Huck, astonished, asks about the paper's significance, Miss Sophia first inquires if he read it and if he can read handwriting. Upon his negative reply (stating he can only read coarse-hand), she dismisses the paper as merely a bookmark and tells him he can go play.

Next Sunday we all went to church, about three mile, everybody a-horseback. The men took their guns along, so did Buck, and kept them between their knees or stood them handy against the wall. The Shepherdsons done the same. It was pretty ornery preaching—all about brotherly love, and such-like tiresomeness; but everybody said it was a good sermon, and they all talked it over going home, and had such a powerful lot to say about faith and good works and free grace and preforeordestination, and I don’t know what all, that it did seem to me to be one of the roughest Sundays I had run across yet.
About an hour after dinner everybody was dozing around, some in their chairs and some in their rooms, and it got to be pretty dull. Buck and a dog was stretched out on the grass in the sun sound asleep. I went up to our room, and judged I would take a nap myself. I found that sweet Miss Sophia standing in her door, which was next to ours, and she took me in her room and shut the door very soft, and asked me if I liked her, and I said I did; and she asked me if I would do something for her and not tell anybody, and I said I would. Then she said she’d forgot her Testament, and left it in the seat at church between two other books, and would I slip out quiet and go there and fetch it to her, and not say nothing to nobody. I said I would. So I slid out and slipped off up the road, and there warn’t anybody at the church, except maybe a hog or two, for there warn’t any lock on the door, and hogs likes a puncheon floor in summer-time because it’s cool. If you notice, most folks don’t go to church only when they’ve got to; but a hog is different.
Says I to myself, something’s up; it ain’t natural for a girl to be in such a sweat about a Testament. So I give it a shake, and out drops a little piece of paper with “Half-past two” wrote on it with a pencil. I ransacked it, but couldn’t find anything else. I couldn’t make anything out of that, so I put the paper in the book again, and when I got home and upstairs there was Miss Sophia in her door waiting for me. She pulled me in and shut the door; then she looked in the Testament till she found the paper, and as soon as she read it she looked glad; and before a body could think she grabbed me and give me a squeeze, and said I was the best boy in the world, and not to tell anybody. She was mighty red in the face for a minute, and her eyes lighted up, and it made her powerful pretty. I was a good deal astonished, but when I got my breath I asked her what the paper was about, and she asked me if I had read it, and I said no, and she asked me if I could read writing, and I told her “no, only coarse-hand,” and then she said the paper warn’t anything but a book-mark to keep her place, and I might go and play now.

It was pretty ornery preaching—all about brotherly love, and such-like tiresomeness; but everybody said it was a good sermon, and they all talked it over going home, and had such a powerful lot to say about faith and good works and free grace and preforeordestination, and I don’t know what all, that it did seem to me to be one of the roughest Sundays I had run across yet.

I never see such a clannish lot as them two families. It was always so. They’d meet up at the church and act mighty friendly, and then as soon as church was over they’d go to carrying their guns again and looking as sour as sin at one another.

About an hour after dinner everybody was dozing around, some in their chairs and some in their rooms, and it got to be pretty dull. Buck and a dog was stretched out on the grass in the sun sound asleep. I went up to my room, and there was Miss Sophia standing in her door, looking kind of uneasy. She took me in her room and shut the door. Then she asked me if I’d do her a favor, and I said I would. She says:

“Run down to the church, Huck, and see if you can find my Testament. I left it in the pew between two other books. Mind, don’t you say nothing about it to anybody.”

I didn’t see nothing out of the way, but I says I would go. She looked pretty uneasy, but I reckoned maybe she was afraid she’d lost the book. I started off, and when I got to the church, I found the door open and went in. It was pretty dim and cool, and there was only a couple of hogs laying in the aisle, taking it easy. I reckoned they had as good a right there as anybody, for hogs likes a cool floor in summer better’n they do a hot sun. Most folks don’t go to church only when they’ve got to; but a hog is different.

I went up to the pew and got the Testament, and as I was going to take it out, I happened to think maybe there was something in it. It seemed kind of curious, her being so anxious about it, so I ransacked it, and shook it, and out fell a little piece of paper with “Half-past two” wrote on it in pencil. I couldn’t make anything out of that, so I put the paper back in the book and took it to the house.

Miss Sophia was standing in her door waiting for me. She pulled me in and shut the door; then she took the Testament and looked for the paper right off. She read it and looked glad; and before a body could think, she grabbed me and hugged me tight, and said I was the best boy in the world, and not to tell anybody. She was mighty red in the face, and her eyes lighted up like you’d never see. She looked so pretty I didn’t know what to do. I was so astonished I couldn’t say a word. She asked me if I’d read the paper, and I said no, and she asked if I could read writing, and I told her only coarse-hand, and then she said it was nothing but a bookmark to keep her place, and I might go and play now.

events.title: Huck's Reunion with Jim, Hidden in the Swamp
detailed_summary: Huck walks towards the river, contemplating Miss Sophia's strange behavior and the mysterious note.
He notices that his assigned slave, Jack, is following him. Once out of sight of the house, Jack runs up to Huck.
Jack offers to show Huck a large quantity of water moccasins in the swamp, a suggestion Huck finds curious as Jack had made the same offer the previous day and Huck isn't particularly fond of snakes.
Despite his suspicion about Jack's motive, Huck agrees and follows him for about a mile, including wading through ankle-deep swamp water.
They arrive at a small, dry, densely wooded patch of land. Jack tells Huck to enter a few steps to find the snakes and then quickly departs.
Huck ventures into the thicket and discovers a small clearing where a man is asleep. To his immense surprise, it is his old companion, Jim.
Huck wakes Jim, expecting his reappearance to be a grand surprise, but Jim, though nearly crying with joy, isn't surprised to see Huck.
Jim recounts that he swam after Huck the night their raft was wrecked, heard Huck's calls but dared not answer for fear of recapture into slavery.
He explains he was injured and fell behind, eventually spotting the Grangerford house. Fearing the dogs, he hid in the woods until morning.

Some of the Grangerford slaves, going to the fields, found him and led him to this secluded spot, which is difficult for dogs to track due to the surrounding water. They have been bringing him food nightly and keeping him informed about Huck's well-being.

Huck asks why Jim didn't have Jack fetch him sooner. Jim explains he didn't want to disturb Huck until they could achieve something, but now they are ready. He reveals he has been buying supplies and, crucially, repairing their old raft at night.

Jim clarifies that their raft wasn't completely destroyed, just damaged, though most of their traps were lost. He explains that if they hadn't been so scared and the night so dark, they might have seen the raft.

Other slaves found the raft caught on a snag nearby and hid it. After some dispute among them about ownership, Jim intervened, claiming the raft belonged to Huck and himself, and settled the matter by giving them ten cents each.
Jim praises these slaves for their kindness and helpfulness, especially Jack, whom he calls smart.
Huck acknowledges Jack's cleverness in arranging the meeting without directly implicating himself, as Jack can truthfully say he never saw Huck and Jim together.

events.text_segment:
I went off down to the river, studying over this thing, and pretty soon I noticed that my nigger was following along behind. When we was out of sight of the house he looked back and around a second, and then comes a-running, and says:
“Mars Jawge, if you’ll come down into de swamp I’ll show you a whole stack o’ water-moccasins.”
Thinks I, that’s mighty curious; he said that yesterday. He oughter know a body don’t love water-moccasins enough to go around hunting for them. What is he up to, anyway? So I says:
“All right; trot ahead.”
I followed a half a mile; then he struck out over the swamp, and waded ankle deep as much as another half-mile. We come to a little flat piece of land which was dry and very thick with trees and bushes and vines, and he says:
“You shove right in dah jist a few steps, Mars Jawge; dah’s whah dey is. I’s seed ’m befo’; I don’t k’yer to see ’em no mo’.”
Then he slopped right along and went away, and pretty soon the trees hid him. I poked into the place a-ways and come to a little open patch as big as a bedroom all hung around with vines, and found a man laying there asleep—and, by jings, it was my old Jim!
I waked him up, and I reckoned it was going to be a grand surprise to him to see me again, but it warn’t. He nearly cried he was so glad, but he warn’t surprised. Said he swum along behind me that night, and heard me yell every time, but dasn’t answer, because he didn’t want nobody to pick him up and take him into slavery again. Says he:
“I got hurt a little, en couldn’t swim fas’, so I wuz a considable ways behine you towards de las’; when you landed I reck’ned I could ketch up wid you on de lan’ ’dout havin’ to shout at you, but when I see dat house I begin to go slow. I ’uz off too fur to hear what dey say to you—I wuz ’fraid o’ de dogs; but when it ’uz all quiet agin, I knowed you’s in de house, so I struck out for de woods to wait for day. Early in de mawnin’ some er de niggers come along, gwyne to de fields, en dey tuk me en showed me dis place, whah de dogs can’t track me on accounts o’ de water, en dey brings me truck to eat every night, en tells me how you’s a-gitt’n along.”
“Why didn’t you tell my Jack to fetch me here sooner, Jim?”
“Well, ’twarn’t no use to ’sturb you, Huck, tell we could do sumfn—but we’s all right now. I ben a-buyin’ pots en pans en vittles, as I got a chanst, en a-patchin’ up de raf’ nights when—”
“What raft, Jim?”
“Our ole raf’.”
“You mean to say our old raft warn’t smashed all to flinders?”
“No, she warn’t. She was tore up a good deal—one en’ of her was; but dey warn’t no great harm done, on’y our traps was mos’ all los’. Ef we hadn’ dive’ so deep en swum so fur under water, en de night hadn’ ben so dark, en we warn’t so sk’yerd, en ben sich punkin-heads, as de sayin’ is, we’d a seed de raf’. But it’s jis’ as well we didn’t, ’kase now she’s all fixed up agin mos’ as good as new, en we’s got a new lot o’ stuff, in de place o’ what ’uz los’.”
“Why, how did you get hold of the raft again, Jim—did you catch her?”
“How I gwyne to ketch her en I out in de woods? No; some er de niggers foun’ her ketched on a snag along heah in de ben’, en dey hid her in a crick ’mongst de willows, en dey wuz so much jawin’ ’bout which un ’um she b’long to de mos’ dat I come to heah ’bout it pooty soon, so I ups en settles de trouble by tellin’ ’um she don’t b’long to none uv um, but to you en me; en I ast ’m if dey gwyne to grab a young white genlman’s propaty, en git a hid’n for it? Den I gin ’m ten cents apiece, en dey ’uz mighty well satisfied, en wisht some mo’ raf’s ’ud come along en make ’m rich agin. Dey’s mighty good to me, dese niggers is, en whatever I wants ’m to do fur me, I doan’ have to ast ’m twice, honey. Dat Jack’s a good nigger, en pooty smart.”
“Yes, he is. He ain’t ever told me you was here; told me to come, and he’d show me a lot of water-moccasins. If anything happens he ain’t mixed up in it. He can say he never seen us together, and it’ll be the truth.”

I went off down to the river, studying over this thing, and pretty soon I noticed that my nigger was following along behind. I didn’t turn around at first, but I could hear his feet in the grass, soft and careful, like he didn’t want to bother me none. The river was running high, and the sun was just coming up over the trees on the far bank, making the water look like it was on fire. I sat down on a log and looked out at it, thinking about what I’d just heard, and what I ought to do next.

Jim came up slow and stood a little ways off, looking at me kind of anxious. I could tell he wanted to say something, but he was waiting for me to speak first. I didn’t know what to say, so I just sat there, picking at the bark on the log and watching the water. After a while, Jim cleared his throat and said, “You’s gwine to tell, ain’t you, Huck?”

I looked at him then, and I could see he was scared. His hands were shaking a little, and his eyes were big and white. I felt bad for him, but I didn’t know what to do. I’d been raised to think it was wrong to help a runaway slave, but Jim was my friend, and I didn’t want to see him get caught. I remembered all the times he’d helped me, and how he’d looked after me when I was sick, and I started to feel all mixed up inside.

“I don’t know, Jim,” I said finally. “I just don’t know.”

Jim sat down on the ground next to me, and we both watched the river for a while without saying anything. The birds were starting to sing in the trees, and the air was cool and fresh. It felt good to be out there, away from everybody else, just me and Jim and the river.

After a while, Jim said, “Huck, I knows it’s hard. But I’s your friend, and you’s mine. I wouldn’t never tell on you, no matter what.”

That made me feel even worse. I didn’t want to let Jim down, but I didn’t want to go against what I’d been taught, neither. I thought about Miss Watson, and how she’d feel if she knew I was helping Jim run away. But then I thought about how Jim had cried when he told me about his family, and how he just wanted to be free so he could go back and get them.

I sat there a long time, thinking about it. The sun was higher now, and the river was sparkling in the light. I could hear the sound of a steamboat in the distance, and I wondered where it was going, and if anybody on it was thinking about the same things I was.

Finally, I made up my mind. I turned to Jim and said, “I ain’t gonna tell, Jim. I ain’t gonna tell nobody. We’ll stick together, and we’ll get you to freedom, somehow.”

Jim’s face lit up, and he grabbed my hand. “Thank you, Huck! Thank you! You’s the best friend I ever had.”

I felt good then, like I’d done the right thing, even if it was hard. I knew it wouldn’t be easy, and there’d be more trouble ahead, but I wasn’t alone. Me and Jim, we’d face it together.

We sat there a while longer, talking about what we’d do next. Jim said we ought to keep moving at night, and hide during the day, so nobody would see us. I agreed, and we made a plan to get some food and supplies before we set out again.

As we walked back to the camp, I felt lighter, like a weight had been lifted off my shoulders. I knew I’d have to answer for what I was doing someday, but for now, I was just glad to have a friend like Jim, and to be free on the river, with the whole world ahead of us.

events.title: Miss Sophia's Elopement Ignites a Deadly Feud Battle
detailed_summary: Huck prefaces the account of the next day with reluctance. He wakes at dawn to an unusual stillness and discovers Buck is gone.
Downstairs, the house is deserted. Outside, Huck encounters Jack, who informs him that Miss Sophia has eloped during the night, presumably with Harney Shepherdson.

The Grangerford family found out about half an hour earlier, leading to a frantic rush for guns and horses. The women went to rally relatives, while Colonel Saul Grangerford and the boys rode upriver to catch and kill Harney before he could cross with Sophia.
Jack explains that Buck also went, determined to bring back a Shepherdson, and that Huck was deliberately not awakened or involved.
Huck rushes up the river road and soon hears gunfire. He climbs a cottonwood tree near the steamboat landing for a better view.
He witnesses four or five mounted men (Shepherdsons) attacking two young individuals hidden behind a wood-rank. Each time a Shepherdson exposes himself, he is shot at.

The two defenders, squatting back-to-back, watch both directions. Eventually, the attackers seem to retreat towards a store, but one of the defenders takes careful aim and shoots one of them from his saddle.
As the remaining Shepherdsons dismount to help their fallen comrade, the two defenders make a run for it, reaching a woodpile near Huck's tree before the pursuing men can catch them.
Huck recognizes one of the boys as Buck and the other as a slim young man of about nineteen, Buck's cousin Joe.

After the attackers temporarily ride off, Huck calls out to Buck, startling him. Buck, distraught and crying, tells Huck his father and two brothers have been killed in an ambush by the Shepherdsons, along with two or three of the enemy. He laments they didn't wait for reinforcements as the Shepherdsons were too strong.
Buck confirms that Harney and Miss Sophia made it safely across the river, which relieves Huck. However, Buck is intensely regretful for not having killed Harney when he had the chance earlier.
Suddenly, three or four gunshots ring out as the Shepherdson men, having dismounted and circled through the woods, attack from behind.
Buck and Joe, both injured, jump into the river. As they swim with the current, the men run along the bank, shooting at them and shouting, "Kill them, kill them!"

The sight makes Huck so sick he nearly falls from the tree. He states he will not recount all the details, as it would make him sick again, and expresses regret for ever coming ashore to witness such horrors, which he knows will haunt his dreams.

events.text_segment:
I don’t want to talk much about the next day. I reckon I’ll cut it pretty short. I waked up about dawn, and was a-going to turn over and go to sleep again, when I noticed how still it was—didn’t seem to be anybody stirring. That warn’t usual. Next I noticed that Buck was up and gone. Well, I gets up, a-wondering, and goes down stairs—nobody around; everything as still as a mouse. Just the same outside. Thinks I, what does it mean? Down by the wood-pile I comes across my Jack, and says:
“What’s it all about?”
Says he:
“Don’t you know, Mars Jawge?”
“No,” says I, “I don’t.”
“Well, den, Miss Sophia’s run off! ’deed she has. She run off in de night some time—nobody don’t know jis’ when; run off to get married to dat young Harney Shepherdson, you know—leastways, so dey ’spec. De fambly foun’ it out ’bout half an hour ago—maybe a little mo’—en’ I tell you dey warn’t no time los’. Sich another hurryin’ up guns en hosses you never see! De women folks has gone for to stir up de relations, en ole Mars Saul en de boys tuck dey guns en rode up de river road for to try to ketch dat young man en kill him ’fo’ he kin git acrost de river wid Miss Sophia. I reck’n dey’s gwyne to be mighty rough times.”
“Buck went off ’thout waking me up.”
“Well, I reck’n he did! Dey warn’t gwyne to mix you up in it. Mars Buck he loaded up his gun en ’lowed he’s gwyne to fetch home a Shepherdson or bust. Well, dey’ll be plenty un ’m dah, I reck’n, en you bet you he’ll fetch one ef he gits a chanst.”
I took up the river road as hard as I could put. By-and-by I begin to hear guns a good ways off. When I come in sight of the log store and the woodpile where the steamboats lands, I worked along under the trees and brush till I got to a good place, and then I clumb up into the forks of a cottonwood that was out of reach, and watched. There was a wood-rank four foot high a little ways in front of the tree, and first I was going to hide behind that; but maybe it was luckier I didn’t.
There was four or five men cavorting around on their horses in the open place before the log store, cussing and yelling, and trying to get at a couple of young chaps that was behind the wood-rank alongside of the steamboat landing; but they couldn’t come it. Every time one of them showed himself on the river side of the woodpile he got shot at. The two boys was squatting back to back behind the pile, so they could watch both ways.
By-and-by the men stopped cavorting around and yelling. They started riding towards the store; then up gets one of the boys, draws a steady bead over the wood-rank, and drops one of them out of his saddle. All the men jumped off of their horses and grabbed the hurt one and started to carry him to the store; and that minute the two boys started on the run. They got half way to the tree I was in before the men noticed. Then the men see them, and jumped on their horses and took out after them. They gained on the boys, but it didn’t do no good, the boys had too good a start; they got to the woodpile that was in front of my tree, and slipped in behind it, and so they had the bulge on the men again. One of the boys was Buck, and the other was a slim young chap about nineteen years old.
The men ripped around awhile, and then rode away. As soon as they was out of sight I sung out to Buck and told him. He didn’t know what to make of my voice coming out of the tree at first. He was awful surprised. He told me to watch out sharp and let him know when the men come in sight again; said they was up to some devilment or other—wouldn’t be gone long. I wished I was out of that tree, but I dasn’t come down. Buck begun to cry and rip, and ’lowed that him and his cousin Joe (that was the other young chap) would make up for this day yet. He said his father and his two brothers was killed, and two or three of the enemy. Said the Shepherdsons laid for them in ambush. Buck said his father and brothers ought to waited for their relations—the Shepherdsons was too strong for them. I asked him what was become of young Harney and Miss Sophia. He said they’d got across the river and was safe. I was glad of that; but the way Buck did take on because he didn’t manage to kill Harney that day he shot at him—I hain’t ever heard anything like it.
All of a sudden, bang! bang! bang! goes three or four guns—the men had slipped around through the woods and come in from behind without their horses! The boys jumped for the river—both of them hurt—and as they swum down the current the men run along the bank shooting at them and singing out, “Kill them, kill them!” It made me so sick I most fell out of the tree. I ain’t a-going to tell all that happened—it would make me sick again if I was to do that. I wished I hadn’t ever come ashore that night to see such things. I ain’t ever going to get shut of them—lots of times I dream about them.

I don’t want to talk much about the next day. I reckon I could say I felt mighty lonesome, and that would be the truth. The sun come up bright and hot, and the river was as still as a picture. I laid there in the shade of the willows, listening to the birds and the water lapping against the bank, and I tried not to think about Pap or Miss Watson or anybody. But it warn’t no use. I kept thinking about Jim, too, and how he was out there somewhere, maybe hungry or scared, and I wished I could do something for him.

After a while, I got up and went down to the water to wash my face and hands. The mud felt cool between my toes, and I splashed around a little, just to feel better. Then I went back to the camp and tried to fix up some breakfast. I had a little corn-dodger left, and I found some berries growing close by, so I made out pretty well. But I kept looking over my shoulder, thinking maybe somebody would come along and catch me.

It warn’t long before I heard a noise in the bushes. My heart jumped up in my throat, and I grabbed my old shotgun, just in case. But it was only a rabbit, hopping along and minding its own business. I laughed a little, feeling foolish, and set the gun down again. I reckon I was getting jumpy, being all alone like that.

The day dragged on slow. I tried fishing, but the fish warn’t biting much. I whittled on a stick for a while, and then I just laid back and watched the clouds drift by. I got to thinking about Tom Sawyer and all the adventures we used to have. I wondered what he’d do if he was in my place. Probably come up with some wild plan, like dressing up as a pirate or something. That made me smile, but it didn’t last long.

By afternoon, I was feeling restless. I decided to take a walk along the riverbank, just to see what I could see. The woods was quiet, except for the birds and the sound of the water. I found a turtle sunning itself on a log, and I watched it for a while. It didn’t seem to have a care in the world. I wished I could be like that turtle, just taking it easy and not worrying about nothing.

As the sun started to go down, I made my way back to camp. I built a little fire and sat by it, watching the flames dance. The night air was cool, and the stars came out one by one. I felt small and alone, but there was something peaceful about it, too. I listened to the frogs and the crickets, and after a while, I started to feel sleepy.

I crawled into my blanket and closed my eyes, but I couldn’t sleep right away. My mind kept wandering, thinking about all the things that had happened and all the things that might happen. I wondered if I’d ever see Jim again, or if I’d ever get back to town. I wondered if Pap was still looking for me, or if he’d given up. I wondered what Miss Watson would say if she knew where I was.

After a long time, I finally drifted off to sleep. I dreamed about floating down the river, with the moon shining on the water and the trees whispering in the breeze. It was a good dream, and I didn’t want to wake up.

But when morning came, I had to face another day. I got up and stretched, feeling stiff and sore. I washed up in the river again and tried to find something to eat. The berries were all gone, and I didn’t have much left. I thought about trying to catch a fish, but I didn’t feel like it. I just sat there, staring at the water and thinking.

It warn’t long before I heard another noise in the bushes. This time, I was ready. I grabbed my shotgun and crept over to where the sound was coming from. I peeked through the leaves and saw a figure moving through the trees. My heart started pounding, and I held my breath.

Then the figure stepped into the clearing, and I saw it was Jim. He looked tired and scared, but when he saw me, he broke into a big grin. I felt a wave of relief wash over me, and I ran over to him.

“Jim!” I whispered. “Where you been?”

He told me he’d been hiding in the woods, trying to keep away from folks. He said he was hungry and tired, and he didn’t know what to do. I gave him the last of my corn-dodger, and we sat down by the fire together.

We talked for a long time, whispering so nobody would hear us. Jim told me about how he’d run away from Miss Watson, and how he was hoping to get to the free states. I told him about Pap and how I’d faked my own death. We both agreed we had to stick together, no matter what.

As the night wore on, we made plans for what to do next. We decided to build a raft and float down the river, keeping out of sight as much as we could. It was risky, but it was the only way we could think of.

We spent the next few days gathering wood and tying it together. It was hard work, but we didn’t mind. We were both glad to have each other for company. We talked and laughed, and for the first time in a while, I didn’t feel so lonesome.

When the raft was finished, we loaded up what little we had and set off down the river. The current was strong, and the water sparkled in the sunlight. I felt free and alive, with the wind in my hair and the world stretching out before me.

We didn’t know what was waiting for us down the river, but we didn’t care. We had each other, and that was enough. As we floated away, I looked back at the shore and felt a pang of sadness. But I knew I couldn’t go back. Not now. Not ever.

events.title: Huck's Traumatic Escape and Joyful Reunion with Jim on the Raft
detailed_summary: Huck remains hidden in the tree until dusk, too scared to descend, as he continues to hear sporadic gunfire and see armed men, indicating the feud is still active.

He feels deeply downhearted and blames himself for the tragic events, believing that if he had revealed Miss Sophia's note and her suspicious behavior to her father, she might have been locked up, preventing the elopement and the ensuing bloodshed.

After climbing down, Huck creeps along the riverbank and finds two bodies at the water's edge. He pulls them ashore and covers their faces; he cries while covering Buck's face, remembering Buck's kindness to him.
It is now dark. Huck avoids the Grangerford house, instead heading through the woods towards the swamp to find Jim.
Jim is not on his usual island hiding spot, so Huck hurries to the creek where the raft was supposedly hidden, only to find the raft gone, which terrifies him momentarily.
Huck yells out, and to his immense relief, Jim's voice answers from nearby. Jim is overjoyed to see Huck, hugging him tightly.

Jim explains that Jack had come and reported that Huck was likely shot because he hadn't returned home. Consequently, Jim was just starting to move the raft down the creek to be ready to leave as soon as Jack confirmed Huck's death.

Huck reassures Jim and explains that his disappearance will lead the Grangerfords to believe he was killed and floated downriver, a belief that will be aided by 'something up there' (likely the bodies he covered). He urges Jim to shove off into the main river immediately.
Huck only feels truly at ease once the raft is two miles downstream and in the middle of the Mississippi River. They light their signal lantern, feeling free and safe once more.
Having not eaten since the previous day, Huck enjoys a meal of corn-dodgers, buttermilk, pork, cabbage, and greens prepared by Jim. While eating, they talk and enjoy their reunion.

Huck expresses his profound gladness to be away from the feuds, and Jim is equally glad to be away from the swamp. They both agree that there is no home like a raft, where one feels free, easy, and comfortable, unlike the cramped and smothery nature of other places.

events.text_segment:
I stayed in the tree till it begun to get dark, afraid to come down. Sometimes I heard guns away off in the woods; and twice I seen little gangs of men gallop past the log store with guns; so I reckoned the trouble was still a-going on. I was mighty downhearted; so I made up my mind I wouldn’t ever go anear that house again, because I reckoned I was to blame, somehow. I judged that that piece of paper meant that Miss Sophia was to meet Harney somewheres at half-past two and run off; and I judged I ought to told her father about that paper and the curious way she acted, and then maybe he would a locked her up, and this awful mess wouldn’t ever happened.
When I got down out of the tree, I crept along down the river bank a piece, and found the two bodies laying in the edge of the water, and tugged at them till I got them ashore; then I covered up their faces, and got away as quick as I could. I cried a little when I was covering up Buck’s face, for he was mighty good to me.
It was just dark now. I never went near the house, but struck through the woods and made for the swamp. Jim warn’t on his island, so I tramped off in a hurry for the crick, and crowded through the willows, red-hot to jump aboard and get out of that awful country. The raft was gone! My souls, but I was scared! I couldn’t get my breath for most a minute. Then I raised a yell. A voice not twenty-five foot from me says:
“Good lan’! is dat you, honey? Doan’ make no noise.”
It was Jim’s voice—nothing ever sounded so good before. I run along the bank a piece and got aboard, and Jim he grabbed me and hugged me, he was so glad to see me. He says:
“Laws bless you, chile, I ’uz right down sho’ you’s dead agin. Jack’s been heah; he say he reck’n you’s ben shot, kase you didn’ come home no mo’; so I’s jes’ dis minute a startin’ de raf’ down towards de mouf er de crick, so’s to be all ready for to shove out en leave soon as Jack comes agin en tells me for certain you is dead. Lawsy, I’s mighty glad to git you back agin, honey.”
I says:
“All right—that’s mighty good; they won’t find me, and they’ll think I’ve been killed, and floated down the river—there’s something up there that’ll help them think so—so don’t you lose no time, Jim, but just shove off for the big water as fast as ever you can.”
I never felt easy till the raft was two mile below there and out in the middle of the Mississippi. Then we hung up our signal lantern, and judged that we was free and safe once more. I hadn’t had a bite to eat since yesterday, so Jim he got out some corn-dodgers and buttermilk, and pork and cabbage and greens—there ain’t nothing in the world so good when it’s cooked right—and whilst I eat my supper we talked, and had a good time. I was powerful glad to get away from the feuds, and so was Jim to get away from the swamp. We said there warn’t no home like a raft, after all. Other places do seem so cramped up and smothery, but a raft don’t. You feel mighty free and easy and comfortable on a raft.

I kept low, and stopped every little bit to listen, but everything was still. When I got to the edge of the water, I looked around, but I didn’t see nobody. The moon was just coming up, and it made the river look all silver and quiet.

I slipped down to the bank and got in the water, and swum out to the middle, where I knowed I’d be safe. I floated along, letting the current take me, and after a while I come to a little island. I crawled up on the sand and laid there, listening to the night noises and trying to think what to do next. I was tired and hungry, but I was glad to be away from them men, and from Pap, and from all the trouble on the shore.

After a while, I got up and wandered around the island. It wasn’t very big, but there was some trees and bushes, and I found a place where I could hide if anybody come. I made up my mind to stay there till I could figure out what to do. I wished I had something to eat, but there wasn’t nothing but some wild berries, and they didn’t go very far. I drunk some water from the river, and then I laid down under a tree and tried to sleep.

I thought about Pap, and hoped he wouldn’t find me. I thought about the men with the guns, and how close they’d come to catching me. It made me shiver to think about it.

After a long time, I must have dozed off, because when I woke up, it was getting light in the east, and the birds was singing. I sat up and stretched, and looked around. Everything was quiet and peaceful, and I felt a little better. I made up my mind to explore the island, and see if I could find something to eat, or maybe a place to build a shelter.

So I started off, keeping close to the trees, and looking careful all around. I found some more berries, and ate them, and then I come to a place where the ground was soft and muddy. I seen some tracks there, and I bent down to look at them. They was fresh, and they wasn’t mine. My heart jumped, and I looked all around, but I didn’t see nobody. I wondered who could be on the island with me. I listened, but everything was still. I begun to feel scared again, but I made up my mind to find out who it was. I followed the tracks, keeping quiet as I could, and pretty soon I come to a little clearing. And there, sitting by a fire, was Jim.

events.title: Idyllic Life and Dawn on the Mississippi
detailed_summary: Several days and nights passed with remarkable tranquility and smoothness for Huck and Jim on the raft.
They established a routine: traveling by night and concealing the raft with freshly cut cottonwoods and willows during daylight hours.
Upon mooring, typically in still water near a tow-head, their first task was to set out fishing lines.
Following this, they would swim in the river to cool off and refresh themselves.
They then sat in the knee-deep sandy shallows, observing the arrival of dawn.
The surroundings were utterly silent, save for the occasional croaking of bullfrogs, creating a sense that the entire world was asleep.
The first visual sign of morning was a faint line of woods on the opposite bank, followed by a growing paleness in the sky.
The river's surface would then soften from black to gray, revealing distant trading scows and rafts as small dark shapes or long streaks.
In the profound stillness, faint sounds like a creaking oar or muffled voices could travel great distances.
They learned to identify snags in swift currents by the streaks they made on the water.
Mist would rise from the river, the eastern sky would redden, and features like log cabins on the far bank, likely woodyards, would become discernible.
A pleasant breeze often carried the scent of woods and flowers, though sometimes it was tainted by the smell of decaying fish.
The arrival of full daylight brought sunshine and the cheerful sound of songbirds.
Once daylight was established and a little smoke wouldn't be easily noticed, they would cook freshly caught fish for a hot breakfast.
After their meal, they would relax, observe the river's vast solitude, and eventually drift off to sleep.

Two or three days and nights went by; I reckon I might say they swum by, they slid along so quiet and smooth and lovely. Here is the way we put in the time. It was a monstrous big river down there—sometimes a mile and a half wide; we run nights, and laid up and hid daytimes; soon as night was most gone we stopped navigating and tied up—nearly always in the dead water under a tow-head; and then cut young cottonwoods and willows, and hid the raft with them. Then we set out the lines. Next we slid into the river and had a swim, so as to freshen up and cool off; then we set down on the sandy bottom where the water was about knee deep, and watched the daylight come. Not a sound anywheres—perfectly still—just like the whole world was asleep, only sometimes the bullfrogs a-cluttering, maybe. The first thing to see, looking away over the water, was a kind of dull line—that was the woods on t’other side; you couldn’t make nothing else out; then a pale place in the sky; then more paleness spreading around; then the river softened up away off, and warn’t black any more, but gray; you could see little dark spots drifting along ever so far away—trading scows, and such things; and long black streaks—rafts; sometimes you could hear a sweep screaking; or jumbled up voices, it was so still, and sounds come so far; and by-and-by you could see a streak on the water which you know by the look of the streak that there’s a snag there in a swift current which breaks on it and makes that streak look that way; and you see the mist curl up off of the water, and the east reddens up, and the river, and you make out a log-cabin in the edge of the woods, away on the bank on t’other side of the river, being a woodyard, likely, and piled by them cheats so you can throw a dog through it anywheres; then the nice breeze springs up, and comes fanning you from over there, so cool and fresh and sweet to smell on account of the woods and the flowers; but sometimes not that way, because they’ve left dead fish laying around, gars and such, and they do get pretty rank; and next you’ve got the full day, and everything smiling in the sun, and the song-birds just going it!
A little smoke couldn’t be noticed now, so we would take some fish off of the lines and cook up a hot breakfast. And afterwards we would watch the lonesomeness of the river, and kind of lazy along, and by-and-by lazy off to sleep.

events.title: Daytime Observations, Fog, and Evening Contemplations on the Raft
detailed_summary: Upon waking during the day, they might spot a distant steamboat, distinguishable only by its type (stern-wheel or side-wheel), followed by periods of profound quiet and isolation.
They observed other rafts passing in the distance, noting the perceptible delay between seeing an axe fall and hearing its impact due to the distance sound traveled over water.
Their days were spent lazily, immersed in the river's stillness.
On one occasion, a dense fog enveloped them, and passing rafts and other vessels would beat tin pans as a warning to steamboats to prevent collisions.
During this fog, they heard men on a nearby, unseen raft talking, cursing, and laughing, which created an eerie, crawly sensation, as if spirits were present.
Jim expressed his belief that these unseen voices belonged to spirits.
Huck, however, pragmatically countered Jim's superstition, reasoning that spirits wouldn't use earthly curses like “Dern the dern fog.”
As night approached, they would push the raft into the river's current, allowing it to float freely.
They would then light their pipes, dangle their legs in the water, and engage in conversations on various topics.
Huck mentions their preference for being naked day and night, weather permitting, as the new clothes from Buck's family were too fine for comfort and he generally wasn't fond of clothing.
They often experienced the sensation of having the entire vast river to themselves for extended periods.
They would observe distant sparks of light, identifying them as candles in cabin windows or lights on other rafts or scows.
Occasionally, the faint sound of a fiddle or a song would drift across the water from these other crafts.
Huck reflects on the loveliness of living on a raft.
They would lie on their backs, gazing at the star-speckled sky, and debate whether the stars were created or simply came into existence on their own.
Jim believed the stars were made, while Huck, considering their vast number, thought they just happened.
Jim proposed that the moon could have laid the stars, an idea Huck found somewhat reasonable by comparing it to a frog laying numerous eggs.
They also watched falling stars, which Jim believed were spoiled stars ejected from their celestial nest.
At night, they would sometimes see steamboats gliding by, emitting showers of sparks from their chimneys that looked beautiful as they fell into the river.
After a steamboat passed and disappeared around a bend, its waves would eventually reach and joggle the raft, followed by a prolonged silence, broken only by natural sounds like frogs.

After midnight, lights from shore cabins would extinguish, indicating that people had gone to bed; these lights served as their clock, and the first reappearance of a light signaled approaching morning, prompting them to quickly find a hiding place.

The next morning we floated down the river, and the sun was shining, and the birds was singing, and everything was fresh and green, and the river was smooth and wide. We felt mighty good, and lazy, and comfortable. Jim said it was a good place to be, and I agreed with him. We didn’t have nothing to do but just float along and watch the world go by. Sometimes we’d fish, and sometimes we’d swim, and sometimes we’d just lay around and talk. It was a lazy, easy life, and we liked it.

Jim would talk about his wife and children, and I’d think about Tom Sawyer, and Aunt Polly, and the old place. But mostly we was contented, and didn’t want to be anywhere else. The river was our home, and we was free and happy there.

events.title: Huck Encounters and Rescues Two Fugitives
detailed_summary: Around daybreak one morning, Huck located a canoe and ventured to the main shore, paddling about a mile up a creek through cypress woods in search of berries.
As he passed a spot where a cowpath intersected the creek, two men suddenly appeared, running down the path in great haste.
Huck's immediate thought was that he or Jim was being pursued, as he always assumed trouble was directed at them.
He was about to make a quick escape, but the men, now very close, called out and implored him to save their lives.
They claimed they had done nothing wrong but were being chased by men and dogs.
They wanted to jump directly into Huck's canoe.
Huck, however, advised them against it, noting he couldn't yet hear dogs or horses, meaning they had time.
He instructed them to push through the brush further up the creek, then enter the water and wade down to him, a tactic designed to throw the pursuing dogs off their scent.
The men followed his directions, and once they were aboard the canoe, Huck sped towards their raft's hiding place at the tow-head.
Within five to ten minutes, they heard the distant shouts of dogs and men.
The pursuers seemed to approach the creek and linger there for a while, though Huck and the escapees couldn't see them.
As Huck paddled further away, the sounds of pursuit grew fainter and eventually ceased altogether.

By the time they had put a mile of woods between them and the creek and reached the main river, all was quiet, and they successfully paddled to the tow-head, concealed themselves in the cottonwoods, and were safe.

One morning about daybreak I found a canoe and crossed over a chute to the main shore—it was only two hundred yards—and paddled about a mile up a crick amongst the cypress woods, to see if I couldn’t get some berries. Just as I was passing a place where a kind of a cowpath crossed the crick, here comes a couple of men tearing up the path as tight as they could foot it. I thought I was a goner, for whenever anybody was after anybody I judged it was me—or maybe Jim. I was about to dig out from there in a hurry, but they was pretty close to me then, and sung out and begged me to save their lives—said they hadn’t been doing nothing, and was being chased for it—said there was men and dogs a-coming. They wanted to jump right in, but I says:
“Don’t you do it. I don’t hear the dogs and horses yet; you’ve got time to crowd through the brush and get up the crick a little ways; then you take to the water and wade down to me and get in—that’ll throw the dogs off the scent.”
They done it, and soon as they was aboard I lit out for our tow-head, and in about five or ten minutes we heard the dogs and the men away off, shouting. We heard them come along towards the crick, but couldn’t see them; they seemed to stop and fool around a while; then, as we got further and further away all the time, we couldn’t hardly hear them at all; by the time we had left a mile of woods behind us and struck the river, everything was quiet, and we paddled over to the tow-head and hid in the cottonwoods and was safe.

events.title: The Fugitives Introduce Themselves and Their Troubles
detailed_summary: Huck provides a description of the two men he rescued.

One was elderly, around seventy or older, with a bald head and very gray whiskers. He wore an old, battered slouch hat, a greasy blue woolen shirt, ragged old blue jeans tucked into his boot-tops, and only one home-knit suspender. He also carried an old long-tailed blue jeans coat with brass buttons over his arm.
The other man was about thirty years old and dressed in a similarly shabby manner.
Both men carried large, dilapidated-looking carpet-bags.
After breakfast, as they all relaxed and talked, it became clear that the two fugitives did not know each other prior to their meeting on the path.
The older man inquired of the younger one about the cause of his trouble.

The younger man explained that he had been selling a tartar-removing product for teeth, which unfortunately also tended to remove tooth enamel. He had lingered in a town one night too long and was making his escape when he encountered the older man on the trail, who warned him of approaching pursuers and asked for help.
The younger man, expecting trouble himself, agreed to flee with the older one.

The older man then shared his own predicament: he had been conducting a successful temperance revival for about a week and was very popular, especially with the women, earning five or six dollars a night.
However, a rumor began circulating the previous night that he secretly indulged in alcohol from a private jug.

A Black person alerted him that morning that a mob was quietly gathering with dogs and horses, intending to give him a brief head start before hunting him down to tar and feather him and ride him on a rail. Consequently, he fled immediately, without waiting for breakfast.

One of these fellows was about seventy or upwards, and had a bald head and very gray whiskers. He had an old battered-up slouch hat on, and a greasy blue woollen shirt, and ragged old blue jeans britches stuffed into his boot-tops, and home-knit galluses—no, he only had one. He had an old long-tailed blue jeans coat with slick brass buttons flung over his arm, and both of them had big, fat, ratty-looking carpet-bags.
The other fellow was about thirty, and dressed about as ornery. After breakfast we all laid off and talked, and the first thing that come out was that these chaps didn’t know one another.
“What got you into trouble?” says the baldhead to t’other chap.
“Well, I’d been selling an article to take the tartar off the teeth—and it does take it off, too, and generly the enamel along with it—but I stayed about one night longer than I ought to, and was just in the act of sliding out when I ran across you on the trail this side of town, and you told me they were coming, and begged me to help you to get off. So I told you I was expecting trouble myself, and would scatter out with you. That’s the whole yarn—what’s yourn?
“Well, I’d ben a-runnin’ a little temperance revival thar, ’bout a week, and was the pet of the women folks, big and little, for I was makin’ it mighty warm for the rummies, I tell you, and takin’ as much as five or six dollars a night—ten cents a head, children and niggers free—and business a-growin’ all the time, when somehow or another a little report got around last night that I had a way of puttin’ in my time with a private jug on the sly. A nigger rousted me out this mornin’, and told me the people was getherin’ on the quiet with their dogs and horses, and they’d be along pretty soon and give me ’bout half an hour’s start, and then run me down if they could; and if they got me they’d tar and feather me and ride me on a rail, sure. I didn’t wait for no breakfast—I warn’t hungry.”

events.title: The Younger Con Man Claims Dukedom and Receives Royal Treatment
detailed_summary: The younger fugitive proposed to the older one that they should team up, an idea the older man was amenable to.
They then discussed their respective 'lines' of work, or rather, their various scams and professions.

The younger man listed his skills as a journeyman printer, dabbling in patent medicines, performing as a tragedy actor, practicing mesmerism and phrenology when opportunities arose, occasionally teaching 'singing-geography' school, and sometimes delivering lectures – essentially, anything that was not conventional work.

The older man mentioned his experience in 'doctoring,' particularly laying on of hands for ailments like cancer and paralysis, fortune-telling (especially when someone else could gather the necessary information for him), preaching, working at camp-meetings, and general missionary work.
Following a pause in conversation, the younger man sighed dramatically and began to lament his current circumstances, expressing sorrow at leading such a life and being 'degraded' into such company.
When the older man questioned his lament, the younger man delivered a self-pitying speech, claiming he had brought his downfall upon himself and deserved his current low state.
He then dramatically revealed what he termed 'the secret of my birth,' proclaiming himself to be, by rights, a duke.
Jim's eyes widened in astonishment, and Huck presumed his own did as well.

The younger man elaborated on his claim, stating he was the rightful Duke of Bridgewater, a lineal descendant of the eldest son of a Duke of Bridgewater who had fled to America. He asserted that the titles and estates had been unjustly seized by a second son, while the infant true duke (his ancestor) was ignored.
He portrayed himself as forlorn, hunted, despised, ragged, heartbroken, and degraded by his association with felons on a raft.
Both Jim and Huck felt immense pity for him. The 'Duke' suggested that acknowledging his rank would comfort him more than anything else.

They agreed to do so, and he instructed them to bow when addressing him, use titles such as 'Your Grace,' 'My Lord,' or 'Your Lordship,' and mentioned he wouldn't mind being called 'Bridgewater.' He also requested that one of them wait on him at dinner and perform any small tasks he desired.

Huck and Jim found these requests easy to fulfill. Throughout dinner, Jim attended to the 'Duke,' asking, 'Will yo’ Grace have some o’ dis or some o’ dat?', which clearly pleased the 'Duke' immensely.

events.text_segment:
“Old man,” said the young one, “I reckon we might double-team it together; what do you think?”
“I ain’t undisposed. What’s your line—mainly?”
“Jour printer by trade; do a little in patent medicines; theater-actor—tragedy, you know; take a turn to mesmerism and phrenology when there’s a chance; teach singing-geography school for a change; sling a lecture sometimes—oh, I do lots of things—most anything that comes handy, so it ain’t work. What’s your lay?”
“I’ve done considerble in the doctoring way in my time. Layin’ on o’ hands is my best holt—for cancer and paralysis, and sich things; and I k’n tell a fortune pretty good when I’ve got somebody along to find out the facts for me. Preachin’s my line, too, and workin’ camp-meetin’s, and missionaryin’ around.”
Nobody never said anything for a while; then the young man hove a sigh and says:
“Alas!”
“What ’re you alassin’ about?” says the baldhead.
“To think I should have lived to be leading such a life, and be degraded down into such company.” And he begun to wipe the corner of his eye with a rag.
“Dern your skin, ain’t the company good enough for you?” says the baldhead, pretty pert and uppish.
“Yes, it is good enough for me; it’s as good as I deserve; for who fetched me so low when I was so high? I did myself. I don’t blame you, gentlemen—far from it; I don’t blame anybody. I deserve it all. Let the cold world do its worst; one thing I know—there’s a grave somewhere for me. The world may go on just as it’s always done, and take everything from me—loved ones, property, everything; but it can’t take that. Some day I’ll lie down in it and forget it all, and my poor broken heart will be at rest.” He went on a-wiping.
“Drot your pore broken heart,” says the baldhead; “what are you heaving your pore broken heart at us f’r? We hain’t done nothing.”
“No, I know you haven’t. I ain’t blaming you, gentlemen. I brought myself down—yes, I did it myself. It’s right I should suffer—perfectly right—I don’t make any moan.”
“Brought you down from whar? Whar was you brought down from?”
“Ah, you would not believe me; the world never believes—let it pass—’tis no matter. The secret of my birth—”
“The secret of your birth! Do you mean to say—”
“Gentlemen,” says the young man, very solemn, “I will reveal it to you, for I feel I may have confidence in you. By rights I am a duke!”
Jim’s eyes bugged out when he heard that; and I reckon mine did, too. Then the baldhead says: “No! you can’t mean it?”
“Yes. My great-grandfather, eldest son of the Duke of Bridgewater, fled to this country about the end of the last century, to breathe the pure air of freedom; married here, and died, leaving a son, his own father dying about the same time. The second son of the late duke seized the titles and estates—the infant real duke was ignored. I am the lineal descendant of that infant—I am the rightful Duke of Bridgewater; and here am I, forlorn, torn from my high estate, hunted of men, despised by the cold world, ragged, worn, heart-broken, and degraded to the companionship of felons on a raft!”
Jim pitied him ever so much, and so did I. We tried to comfort him, but he said it warn’t much use, he couldn’t be much comforted; said if we was a mind to acknowledge him, that would do him more good than most anything else; so we said we would, if he would tell us how. He said we ought to bow when we spoke to him, and say “Your Grace,” or “My Lord,” or “Your Lordship”—and he wouldn’t mind it if we called him plain “Bridgewater,” which, he said, was a title anyway, and not a name; and one of us ought to wait on him at dinner, and do any little thing for him he wanted done.
Well, that was all easy, so we done it. All through dinner Jim stood around and waited on him, and says, “Will yo’ Grace have some o’ dis or some o’ dat?” and so on, and a body could see it was mighty pleasing to him.

The old man looked at the young one, his eyes narrowing with a shrewd calculation. He scratched his head, as if pondering the proposition, and then let a slow, sly smile spread across his face. “Well, I don’t see why not, my boy,” he replied, his voice oozing with a kind of oily charm. “Two heads is better’n one, as the saying goes, and I reckon we might make a right smart team, if we put our minds to it.”

The young one grinned, pleased with the old man’s answer. He straightened up, dusting off his ragged coat, and looked around at the little group gathered on the bank of the river. Huck watched them both, feeling a mixture of curiosity and unease. He had seen enough of the world to know that when two such characters joined forces, there was bound to be some mischief afoot.

Jim, standing close by, shifted his weight from one foot to the other, his eyes darting nervously between the two strangers. He leaned in close to Huck and whispered, “I don’ like de look o’ dem two, Huck. Dey’s up to somethin’, I knows it.”

Huck nodded, but said nothing. He was thinking hard, trying to figure out what the old man and the young one were planning. The old man, meanwhile, was already spinning a tale, his words flowing smooth and easy, like a river in flood.

“Now, gentlemen,” he said, addressing Huck and Jim as if they were part of his audience, “I reckon it’s only fair to introduce ourselves, seein’ as how we’re all travelin’ together now. My name, sirs, is the Reverend Alexander Blodgett, D.D., late of the church of—well, never mind where. And this here,” he gestured to the young man, “is my esteemed friend, the rightful Duke of Bridgewater.”

The young man tipped his hat, a sly grin on his face. “That’s right, gentlemen. The Duke of Bridgewater, at your service.”

Huck tried to keep a straight face, but inside he was laughing. He knew these two were nothing but frauds, but he decided to play along for now. “Pleased to meet you, your grace,” he said, bowing low. “And you too, Reverend.”

The old man beamed, clearly pleased with Huck’s show of respect. “Thank you, my boy, thank you. It does my heart good to meet such well-mannered young men in these rough times.”

Jim, however, was not so easily fooled. He eyed the two men suspiciously, but said nothing. He knew better than to cross men like these, at least not until he had a better sense of what they were after.

The four of them set off down the river together, the old man and the young one talking in low voices, plotting and scheming. Huck listened as best he could, trying to catch snatches of their conversation, but they were careful to keep their voices low.

As the days passed, Huck watched the two men closely. They were always coming up with new schemes, trying to swindle the people they met along the river. Sometimes they argued, each one trying to outdo the other with his lies and tricks. But for all their bluster, Huck could see that they were both scared men, always looking over their shoulders, afraid of being caught.

One night, as they sat around the campfire, the old man began to tell a story about his days as a preacher. He spoke of the souls he had saved, the sermons he had preached, and the miracles he had performed. The young one listened with a smirk, clearly not believing a word of it.

Huck listened too, but he was more interested in what the old man wasn’t saying. He could tell that the story was mostly lies, but he was curious to see how far the old man would go.

After a while, the old man finished his story and looked around the fire. “Well, boys,” he said, “I reckon it’s time to turn in. We got a long day ahead of us tomorrow, and we’ll need all our wits about us.”

The others nodded, and soon they were all lying down, the fire burning low. Huck lay awake for a long time, thinking about the two men and their schemes. He knew he had to be careful, but he also knew that as long as he kept his wits about him, he could handle whatever came his way.

events.title: The Older Con Man Claims to Be the Lost King of France
detailed_summary: The older man grew noticeably quiet and appeared uncomfortable witnessing the deferential treatment the 'Duke' was receiving.
He seemed to be contemplating something, and later in the afternoon, he addressed the 'Duke' (calling him 'Bilgewater'), stating that the 'Duke' wasn't the only one who had experienced such troubles.
He asserted that the 'Duke' was not unique in being wrongfully brought down from a high position or in having a secret of his birth, and then the older man himself began to cry.

When pressed, the older man, after securing a promise of trust from the 'Duke,' dramatically revealed his own secret: he declared himself to be the 'late Dauphin,' Louis XVII, son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette, the rightful King of France.
This revelation caused Huck and Jim to stare in amazement. The 'Duke' expressed skepticism, particularly regarding the older man's age in relation to the historical Dauphin.

The older man attributed his aged appearance, gray hairs, and premature baldness to 'trouble,' presenting himself as the wandering, exiled, trampled-on, and suffering King of France, clad in blue jeans and misery.
Moved by his sorrowful display, Huck and Jim felt both pity and a sense of pride at having such an eminent personage with them. They began to comfort him as they had the 'Duke.'

The 'King' claimed that only death could truly relieve his suffering, but he admitted that being treated according to his royal rights often made him feel better. He requested that people kneel when speaking to him, always call him 'Your Majesty,' serve him first at meals, and not sit in his presence until invited.
Huck and Jim readily complied, bestowing royal honors upon him, which significantly cheered him up.

However, the 'Duke' became somewhat resentful of the new hierarchy and the attention the 'King' was receiving. Despite this, the 'King' acted very friendly towards the 'Duke,' mentioning that his (the King's) father had held the Duke's ancestors in high regard.

After the 'Duke' remained disgruntled for some time, the 'King' philosophically reasoned with him. He pointed out that they would likely be together on the raft for a long time, so being sour would only create discomfort. He emphasized that it wasn't his fault he wasn't born a duke, nor the 'Duke's' fault he wasn't born a king, so there was no use in worrying. He advocated for making the best of their situation and offered his hand in friendship.
The 'Duke' accepted this gesture, and Huck and Jim were greatly pleased, as it dispelled the tension and restored harmony on the raft, which they valued highly for peaceful coexistence.
