He said he’d left it on the table in the kitchen, and Aunt Sally was in there, so he couldn’t get it. I said, “Why, Tom, we can’t get along without it.”

He said, “Well, then, we’ll have to do without it.”

I said, “But looky here, Tom, Aunt Sally’ll miss it and we’ll get into trouble.”

He said, “Oh, she won’t miss it; she’s got plenty more.”

I said, “That ain’t the thing—the thing is, if she misses one, she’ll suspect something. That’s the way with women; they always notice the least little thing, and they’re always a-bothering over it.”

He said, “Well, then, I’ll go and get it.”

So he slipped back and by and by he come along with the spoon, and we put it in the sack and started off again, and everything was all right. But I was a good deal bothered about it, and I kept thinking and thinking, and I couldn’t see how we was going to get through with all these things without being found out. But Tom he said we’d manage it somehow, and not to worry.

events.title: The Sheet-Counting Deception and Resolution of Missing Items
detailed_summary: The boys employed a similar deceptive tactic with the sheets.
They returned the original missing sheet to the clothesline that night but then stole a different one from Aunt Sally's closet.
They repeated this process of returning one sheet and stealing another for a couple of days.
This manipulation led Aunt Sally to become completely confused about the actual number of sheets she possessed.
Eventually, she grew indifferent to the count and resolved to stop worrying about it, refusing to count them again under any circumstances.

Huck concluded that they had successfully resolved the mysteries of the missing shirt (attributed to the calf), the sheet and spoon (through confusing Aunt Sally's counts), and the candles (blamed on rats).
The missing candlestick was deemed inconsequential and expected to be forgotten over time.
The narrative then shifts, with Huck noting that their next significant challenge was the difficult task of baking the pie for Jim.

events.title: The Complicated Process of Making the Rope Ladder Pie
detailed_summary: The boys undertook the baking of the special pie in a secluded location in the woods.
This proved to be a challenging and lengthy endeavor, not completed within a single day.
They used a substantial amount of flour, equivalent to three washpans full.
During the process, they sustained minor burns and suffered from smoke irritating their eyes.
The primary difficulty was creating a hollow pie crust that would maintain its shape without collapsing, as they only needed the outer shell.
They eventually conceived the idea of baking the rope ladder inside the pie to provide internal support for the crust.
Collaborating with Jim on the second night, they meticulously fashioned a rope ladder by shredding a sheet into thin strips and twisting them together, finishing the task before daylight.
They planned to tell Jim that the ladder's intricate construction had taken nine months to complete.

events.title: Baking the Pie in the Ancestral Warming-Pan
detailed_summary: When they brought the finished rope ladder to their woodland baking site, they found it was far too large for a single pie, as it had been made from an entire bedsheet.
Realizing they only needed enough rope for one pie, they discarded the excess.
They decided against using their tin washpan for baking, fearing its solder might melt under the heat.

Instead, they secretly retrieved Uncle Silas's valuable brass warming-pan, an heirloom with a long wooden handle that had supposedly come from England with an early colonist, from its storage place in the garret.
Their initial attempts to bake the pie using the warming-pan were unsuccessful due to their inexperience with it.
However, they persisted and finally achieved success on their last attempt.
They lined the warming-pan with dough, placed the rag rope ladder inside, covered it with a dough roof, sealed the lid, and then applied hot embers to the top and bottom for even baking.
After approximately fifteen minutes, the warming-pan produced a pie that was visually perfect and satisfying to behold.
Huck humorously commented that anyone attempting to eat the pie would find the rope ladder filling highly indigestible and would likely suffer significant stomach discomfort.

And in the forenoon we took it down to the woods, but it wouldn’t go into the pie. Being made of a whole sheet, that way, there was rope enough for forty pies if we’d a wanted them, and plenty left over for soup, or sausage, or anything you choose. We could a had a whole dinner.
But we didn’t need it. All we needed was just enough for the pie, and so we throwed the rest away. We didn’t cook none of the pies in the wash-pan—afraid the solder would melt; but Uncle Silas he had a noble brass warming-pan which he thought considerable of, because it belonged to one of his ancesters with a long wooden handle that come over from England with William the Conqueror in the Mayflower or one of them early ships and was hid away up garret with a lot of other old pots and things that was valuable, not on account of being any account, because they warn’t, but on account of them being relicts, you know, and we snaked her out, private, and took her down there, but she failed on the first pies, because we didn’t know how, but she come up smiling on the last one. We took and lined her with dough, and set her in the coals, and loaded her up with rag rope, and put on a dough roof, and shut down the lid, and put hot embers on top, and stood off five foot, with the long handle, cool and comfortable, and in fifteen minutes she turned out a pie that was a satisfaction to look at. But the person that et it would want to fetch a couple of kags of toothpicks along, for if that rope ladder wouldn’t cramp him down to business I don’t know nothing what I’m talking about, and lay him in enough stomach-ache to last him till next time, too.

events.title: Delivery of the Pie and Jim's Resourceful Actions
detailed_summary: The boys discreetly placed the specially prepared "witch pie," containing the rope ladder, into Jim's food pan, ensuring Nat, Jim's attendant, did not observe them.
They also hid three tin plates at the bottom of the pan, underneath Jim's meal.
Jim successfully received all the items intended for him.
Once he was alone, Jim broke open the pie to access its contents.
He carefully extracted the rope ladder and concealed it within the straw of his mattress.
He then used one of the tin plates to scratch some kind of message or marks on it, before throwing the inscribed plate out through the small window opening of his cabin.

events.title: Designing the Prisoner's Legacy: Inscriptions and a Coat of Arms
detailed_summary: The creation of makeshift pens and a saw is proving to be a challenging endeavor, and Jim expresses his belief that carving an inscription will be the most difficult task of all.
Tom Sawyer insists that, like all notable state prisoners from history such as Lady Jane Grey, Jim must leave behind a carved inscription and a coat of arms.
Jim is bewildered, pointing out that he possesses only his old shirt, which he is already supposed to use for keeping a journal.
Tom clarifies that a coat of arms is a distinct heraldic emblem, not an item of clothing, a point Huck Finn tries to support by affirming Jim doesn't own one.
Tom remains adamant, declaring that Jim will have a proper coat of arms before his escape to ensure every detail is authentic and there are no 'flaws in his record.'
While Huck and Jim laboriously fashion pens—Jim from brass, Huck from a spoon—Tom dedicates himself to conceptualizing Jim's coat of arms.

Tom unveils a highly elaborate and complex design for the coat of arms, replete with obscure heraldic terms and symbols, including a motto, 'Maggiore fretta, minore atto,' which he translates as 'the more haste, the less speed.'
Huck, confused by the jargon, asks for clarification on terms like 'fess' and 'bar sinister,' but Tom deflects his questions, claiming lack of time or necessity for Huck to understand.
With the coat of arms designed, Tom shifts his focus to composing suitably mournful inscriptions for Jim to carve, as was customary for prisoners.

He drafts several dramatic inscriptions, such as 'Here a captive heart busted,' and 'Here, homeless and friendless, after thirty-seven years of bitter captivity, perished a noble stranger, natural son of Louis XIV.'
Tom is visibly moved while reading his compositions and, unable to choose the best one, decides Jim should carve all of them.
Jim protests the immense labor this would involve, particularly given his inability to make letters, but Tom offers to sketch the outlines for him.
Tom then revises his plan, realizing that log walls are inappropriate for a dungeon setting and that the inscriptions must be carved into a rock.
Jim laments that carving into rock would be an even more arduous and lengthy task, but Tom volunteers Huck to assist Jim.

Noticing the slow and painful progress Huck and Jim are making on the pens, Tom devises a new plan: they will steal a large grindstone from the local mill. This grindstone will serve for carving the coat of arms and inscriptions, as well as for sharpening their tools.

events.text_segment:
Making them pens was a distressid tough job, and so was the saw; and Jim allowed the inscription was going to be the toughest of all. That’s the one which the prisoner has to scrabble on the wall. But he had to have it; Tom said he’d got to; there warn’t no case of a state prisoner not scrabbling his inscription to leave behind, and his coat of arms.
“Look at Lady Jane Grey,” he says; “look at Gilford Dudley; look at old Northumberland! Why, Huck, s’pose it is considerble trouble?—what you going to do?—how you going to get around it? Jim’s got to do his inscription and coat of arms. They all do.”
Jim says:
“Why, Mars Tom, I hain’t got no coat o’ arm; I hain’t got nuffn but dish yer ole shirt, en you knows I got to keep de journal on dat.”
“Oh, you don’t understand, Jim; a coat of arms is very different.”
“Well,” I says, “Jim’s right, anyway, when he says he ain’t got no coat of arms, because he hain’t.”
“I reckon I knowed that,” Tom says, “but you bet he’ll have one before he goes out of this—because he’s going out right, and there ain’t going to be no flaws in his record.”
So whilst me and Jim filed away at the pens on a brickbat apiece, Jim a-making his’n out of the brass and I making mine out of the spoon, Tom set to work to think out the coat of arms. By-and-by he said he’d struck so many good ones he didn’t hardly know which to take, but there was one which he reckoned he’d decide on. He says:
“On the scutcheon we’ll have a bend or in the dexter base, a saltire murrey in the fess, with a dog, couchant, for common charge, and under his foot a chain embattled, for slavery, with a chevron vert in a chief engrailed, and three invected lines on a field azure, with the nombril points rampant on a dancette indented; crest, a runaway nigger, sable, with his bundle over his shoulder on a bar sinister; and a couple of gules for supporters, which is you and me; motto, Maggiore fretta, minore atto. Got it out of a book—means the more haste, the less speed.”
“Geewhillikins,” I says, “but what does the rest of it mean?”
“We ain’t got no time to bother over that,” he says; “we got to dig in like all git-out.”
“Well, anyway,” I says, “what’s some of it? What’s a fess?”
“A fess—a fess is—you don’t need to know what a fess is. I’ll show him how to make it when he gets to it.”
“Shucks, Tom,” I says, “I think you might tell a person. What’s a bar sinister?”
“Oh, I don’t know. But he’s got to have it. All the nobility does.”
That was just his way. If it didn’t suit him to explain a thing to you, he wouldn’t do it. You might pump at him a week, it wouldn’t make no difference.
He’d got all that coat of arms business fixed, so now he started in to finish up the rest of that part of the work, which was to plan out a mournful inscription—said Jim got to have one, like they all done. He made up a lot, and wrote them out on a paper, and read them off, so:
1. Here a captive heart busted.
2. Here a poor prisoner, forsook by the world and friends, fretted out his sorrowful life.
3. Here a lonely heart broke, and a worn spirit went to its rest, after thirty-seven years of solitary captivity.
4. Here, homeless and friendless, after thirty-seven years of bitter captivity, perished a noble stranger, natural son of Louis XIV.
Tom’s voice trembled whilst he was reading them, and he most broke down. When he got done he couldn’t no way make up his mind which one for Jim to scrabble on to the wall, they was all so good; but at last he allowed he would let him scrabble them all on. Jim said it would take him a year to scrabble such a lot of truck on to the logs with a nail, and he didn’t know how to make letters, besides; but Tom said he would block them out for him, and then he wouldn’t have nothing to do but just follow the lines. Then pretty soon he says:
“Come to think, the logs ain’t a-going to do; they don’t have log walls in a dungeon: we got to dig the inscriptions into a rock. We’ll fetch a rock.”
Jim said the rock was worse than the logs; he said it would take him such a pison long time to dig them into a rock he wouldn’t ever get out. But Tom said he would let me help him do it. Then he took a look to see how me and Jim was getting along with the pens. It was most pesky tedious hard work and slow, and didn’t give my hands no show to get well of the sores, and we didn’t seem to make no headway, hardly; so Tom says:
“I know how to fix it. We got to have a rock for the coat of arms and mournful inscriptions, and we can kill two birds with that same rock. There’s a gaudy big grindstone down at the mill, and we’ll smouch it, and carve the things on it, and file out the pens and the saw on it, too.”

So Jim said, what’s a coat of arms? Tom says it’s a thing a prisoner has to scrabble on the wall; but he’s got to have it, so Jim said he’d let it go, if Tom would tell him what it was. Tom said it was a thing that was made up of signs, and marks, and pictures, and letters, and words, and so on, and said that the prisoner had to have it, or he wouldn’t be in the fashion and wouldn’t be respected. Jim said he didn’t see no use in it, but he was willing to do whatever Tom said. So Tom set to work to think out a coat of arms. By and by he said he’d struck so many good ones he didn’t hardly know which to take, but there was one which he reckoned he’d decide on. He says:

“On the scutcheon we’ll have a bend or in the dexter base, a saltire murrey in the fess, with a dog, couchant, for common charge, and under his foot a chain embattled, for slavery, with a chevron vert in a chief engrailed, and three invected lines on a field azure, with the nombril points rampant on a dancette indented; crest, a runaway nigger, sable, with his bundle over his shoulder on a bar sinister; and a couple of gules for supporters, which is you and me; motto, Maggiore fretta, minore atto. Got it out of a book—means the more haste the less speed.”

Jim didn’t understand it at all, but he didn’t care, because it was Tom’s notion, and he was willing to do whatever Tom said. Tom said he would draw it out for him on a piece of paper, and then Jim could copy it on the wall. Jim said he couldn’t make letters, and Tom said he would print them off for him, and then he could copy them. So that was all right.

Then Tom says:

“Now, we’ll start the inscription.”

So he wrote:

“Here a captive heart busted.”

Tom said that was very good, but he guessed there were better ones. So he wrote:

“Here, homeless and friendless, after thirty-seven years of bitter captivity, perished a noble stranger, natural son of Louis XIV.”

Tom’s eyes lit up, and he says:

“That’ll do. It’s the best one yet. But I reckon we’ll let him carve them all.”

Jim said it would take him a year to carve such a lot of things, and he didn’t know how. But Tom said he would show him how, and if he couldn’t do it, he would help him. Then Tom said the wall wasn’t the right place for it, anyway, because a prisoner’s inscription is always carved on a rock. So they must find a rock. Jim said the rock was worse than the wall; he’d never get through with it. But Tom said he would help him, and besides, he could get Huck to help, too. Then Tom saw how slow they were making pens and things, and he said they must have a grindstone; he’d seen one in the mill, and they could roll it in and use it for grinding the pens and for carving the inscription and the coat of arms and all that.

We tied the sheets together, and made a good strong ladder, and hid it under the bed. Tom said we had to have some candles, too, so Jim could read by them at night. He said we could make them out of tallow, and we did. We made a couple of candles, and put them in the room. Jim said he didn't need them, but Tom said it was the style, and we had to have them.

Tom said we had to have a cat, too, but I said I didn't know where we could get one. Tom said we could catch one in the woods, but I said I didn't think there was any cats in the woods. Tom said it didn't matter, we could just pretend. So we did.

events.title: The Grindstone Heist and Inscription Work
detailed_summary: Huck acknowledges Tom's idea to use a grindstone is clever, though the grindstone itself is very large and heavy, presenting a significant challenge.
They decide to proceed with the theft, setting out for the mill before midnight while Jim continues his other assigned tasks.
Huck and Tom successfully 'smouch' (steal) the grindstone but find it exceedingly difficult to transport, struggling to roll it and narrowly avoiding being crushed by it multiple times.
Completely exhausted and drenched in sweat after getting it halfway, they admit defeat and realize they require Jim's superior strength.
Jim is summoned; he detaches his leg chain from the bed, wraps it around his neck for concealment, and exits through their escape tunnel.
With Jim's help, moving the massive grindstone becomes almost effortless, while Tom assumes a supervisory role, which Huck notes Tom performs with great aptitude.
The existing escape hole proves too small for the grindstone, prompting Jim to use a pickaxe to quickly enlarge it.
Once the grindstone is inside the hut, Tom uses a nail to sketch out the designs for the inscriptions and coat of arms.
Jim is then set to the task of carving these into the stone, using the nail as a chisel and an iron bolt found in nearby rubbish as a makeshift hammer.
Tom instructs Jim to work until his candle burns out, after which he should hide the grindstone under his straw mattress and sleep on it.
Finally, Huck and Tom assist Jim in re-securing his chain to the bed-leg, and the boys prepare to go to sleep.

events.text_segment:
It warn’t no slouch of an idea; and it warn’t no slouch of a grindstone nuther; but we allowed we’d tackle it. It warn’t quite midnight yet, so we cleared out for the mill, leaving Jim at work. We smouched the grindstone, and set out to roll her home, but it was a most nation tough job. Sometimes, do what we could, we couldn’t keep her from falling over, and she come mighty near mashing us every time. Tom said she was going to get one of us, sure, before we got through. We got her half way; and then we was plumb played out, and most drownded with sweat. We see it warn’t no use; we got to go and fetch Jim. So he raised up his bed and slid the chain off of the bed-leg, and wrapt it round and round his neck, and we crawled out through our hole and down there, and Jim and me laid into that grindstone and walked her along like nothing; and Tom superintended. He could out-superintend any boy I ever see. He knowed how to do everything.
Our hole was pretty big, but it warn’t big enough to get the grindstone through; but Jim he took the pick and soon made it big enough. Then Tom marked out them things on it with the nail, and set Jim to work on them, with the nail for a chisel and an iron bolt from the rubbage in the lean-to for a hammer, and told him to work till the rest of his candle quit on him, and then he could go to bed, and hide the grindstone under his straw tick and sleep on it. Then we helped him fix his chain back on the bed-leg, and was ready for bed ourselves.

events.title: Tom's Zoological Theatrics: Spiders, Snakes, and Jim's Protests
detailed_summary: Just as they are about to sleep, Tom conceives another idea for Jim's imprisonment, asking if Jim has any spiders in his dwelling.
Jim replies that he does not, expressing gratitude for their absence as he is afraid of them.
Tom announces their intention to procure some spiders for Jim.
Jim implores them not to, reiterating his fear of spiders.
Tom then escalates his idea, suggesting a rattlesnake would be a 'prime good idea' for a prisoner's pet, speculating it must have been done before.
Jim reacts with sheer terror, declaring he would break out of the hut if a rattlesnake were introduced.
Tom attempts to placate Jim, arguing that he could tame the rattlesnake, as animals supposedly respond to kindness, and even suggests Jim could let it sleep with him and put its head in his mouth.
Jim is profoundly disturbed by this notion and vehemently refuses, finding the idea of such intimacy with a snake repulsive.
Tom insists that a prisoner must have a 'dumb pet' and that taming a rattlesnake would bring Jim unique glory.
Jim counters that he desires no such glory, especially if it involves being bitten and potentially losing his chin.
Tom pressures Jim to at least try taming a rattlesnake, but Jim stands firm, stating he will leave if they bring one into the hut.

Frustrated by Jim's 'bull-headedness,' Tom concedes on the rattlesnake but proposes a compromise: they will get garter snakes, and Jim can tie buttons to their tails to make them resemble rattlesnakes.
Jim reluctantly accepts the garter snakes, though he would prefer to have no snakes at all, and remarks on the unexpected amount of bother and trouble involved in being a prisoner 'done right.'

But Tom thought of something, and says:
“You got any spiders in here, Jim?”
“No, sah, thanks to goodness I hain’t, Mars Tom.”
“All right, we’ll get you some.”
“But bless you, honey, I doan’ want none. I’s afeard un um. I jis’ ’s soon have rattlesnakes aroun’.”
Tom thought a minute or two, and says:
“It’s a good idea. And I reckon it’s been done. It must a been done; it stands to reason. Yes, it’s a prime good idea. Where could you keep it?”
“Keep what, Mars Tom?”
“Why, a rattlesnake.”
“De goodness gracious alive, Mars Tom! Why, if dey was a rattlesnake to come in heah I’d take en bust right out thoo dat log wall, I would, wid my head.”
“Why, Jim, you wouldn’t be afraid of it after a little. You could tame it.”
“Tame it!”
“Yes—easy enough. Every animal is grateful for kindness and petting, and they wouldn’t think of hurting a person that pets them. Any book will tell you that. You try—that’s all I ask; just try for two or three days. Why, you can get him so, in a little while, that he’ll love you; and sleep with you; and won’t stay away from you a minute; and will let you wrap him round your neck and put his head in your mouth.”
“Please, Mars Tom—doan’ talk so! I can’t stan’ it! He’d let me shove his head in my mouf—fer a favor, hain’t it? I lay he’d wait a pow’ful long time ’fo’ I ast him. En mo’ en dat, I doan’ want him to sleep wid me.”
“Jim, don’t act so foolish. A prisoner’s got to have some kind of a dumb pet, and if a rattlesnake hain’t ever been tried, why, there’s more glory to be gained in your being the first to ever try it than any other way you could ever think of to save your life.”
“Why, Mars Tom, I doan’ want no sich glory. Snake take ’n bite Jim’s chin off, den whah is de glory? No, sah, I doan’ want no sich doin’s.”
“Blame it, can’t you try? I only want you to try—you needn’t keep it up if it don’t work.”
“But de trouble all done ef de snake bite me while I’s a tryin’ him. Mars Tom, I’s willin’ to tackle mos’ anything ’at ain’t onreasonable, but ef you en Huck fetches a rattlesnake in heah for me to tame, I’s gwyne to leave, dat’s shore.”
“Well, then, let it go, let it go, if you’re so bull-headed about it. We can get you some garter-snakes, and you can tie some buttons on their tails, and let on they’re rattlesnakes, and I reckon that’ll have to do.”
“I k’n stan’ dem, Mars Tom, but blame’ ’f I couldn’ get along widout um, I tell you dat. I never knowed b’fo’ ’t was so much bother and trouble to be a prisoner.”

"Say, Huck, if we find the money, we can get out of here mighty quick, can't we? But we got to be careful. We can't let on to anybody. Not even old Miss Watson or Aunt Polly. You know how women is—they'd be a-blabbing it all over town before you could say Jack Robinson."

I says, "That's so, Tom. But how are we going to get at it? The robbers might come back any minute."

Tom studied a minute, then he grinned. "We'll just have to be smarter than them, that's all. Remember how we did with the gang? We made up all them rules and signs and things. Well, this is just like that, only real."

I looked at Tom, and I could see he was enjoying himself. He always did like a good adventure, and this was the best one yet. "All right," I says, "but we got to be quick."

Tom nodded. "First, we got to make sure the coast is clear. You go peek out that crack in the wall, and I'll keep an eye on the door. If you see anybody, just give a little cough, like this—" and he made a sound like a frog croaking.

I crept over to the crack and looked out. The moon was shining bright, and I could see the river glimmering through the trees. There warn't nobody in sight. I turned back to Tom and shook my head.

"All right," he whispered. "Now, let's look for the money."

We started poking around the old cabin, feeling under the floorboards and behind the barrels. It was dark, and every little noise made me jump. I kept thinking about the robbers coming back and catching us. But Tom, he warn't scared a bit. He just kept on searching, whistling soft to himself.

After a while, I found a loose board in the corner. I pried it up with my knife, and there, sure enough, was a little sack tied up with string. My heart jumped up in my throat. "Tom!" I whispered. "I found it!"

Tom came running over, his eyes shining. He grabbed the sack and untied the string. Inside was a pile of gold coins, all bright and shiny. We stared at them, hardly believing our luck.

"We done it, Huck!" Tom whispered. "We're rich!"

I couldn't hardly speak. I just nodded, feeling like I was in a dream.

"Now," Tom said, "we got to get out of here before anybody comes. We'll hide the money in the woods, and then we can figure out what to do next."

We slipped out of the cabin, quiet as mice, and ran through the trees to a little hollow we knew about. We buried the sack under a big rock, and covered it up with leaves and sticks.

"Nobody'll ever find it there," Tom said, grinning.

I nodded. "I reckon you're right."

We sat there a minute, catching our breath, and then Tom says, "This is the best adventure we ever had, Huck."

And I had to agree with him.

events.title: Prisonerly Pursuits: Rats, Melancholy Music, and a Tear-Watered Flower
detailed_summary: Responding to Jim's lament, Tom asserts that authentic imprisonment is inherently troublesome and immediately inquires if Jim has any rats.
Jim confirms he hasn't seen any rats in the hut.
Tom declares that they will provide Jim with some rats.
Jim objects, describing rats as disruptive and prone to biting sleeping individuals, stating he would prefer garter snakes if he must have animal companions, but definitely not rats.
Tom insists that rats are a standard feature of imprisonment, claiming all prisoners have them, train them, pet them, and make them sociable, often using music.
He asks Jim if he has any musical instrument.
Jim mentions having a coarse comb, a piece of paper, and a jews-harp, expressing doubt that rats would appreciate the jews-harp.

Tom reassures Jim that a jews-harp is perfectly adequate, as all animals, especially in prison, are fond of music, particularly 'painful music' like that produced by a jews-harp, which piques their curiosity.

Tom instructs Jim to play 'The Last Link is Broken' on his jews-harp at night before sleeping and early in the mornings. He claims this will attract all the rats, snakes, spiders, and other creatures, who will then 'swarm over' Jim and have a 'noble good time.'
Jim dryly questions what sort of experience this will be for him but resignedly agrees to comply to keep the animals 'satisfied.'
After some thought, Tom recalls another 'forgotten' detail: Jim should cultivate a flower in his prison.
Jim expresses skepticism, citing the darkness of the hut and the considerable effort involved, adding that he has no personal use for a flower.
Tom insists, mentioning that other prisoners have successfully grown flowers.
Jim suggests that a mullen-stalk might grow but reiterates that it would be far more trouble than it's worth.
Tom instructs Jim to call the plant 'Pitchiola,' its 'right name' in a prison context, and to water it with his tears, as is traditional for prisoners.
Jim argues that spring water would be more effective for growing the plant, especially since he rarely cries.
Stumped by Jim's lack of tears, Tom proposes a solution: Jim will have to use an onion to induce crying, promising to secretly place one in Jim's coffee pot the next morning.

Jim complains vociferously about the onion and the cumulative burden of all Tom's elaborate plans—making pens, carving inscriptions, keeping journals, managing rats, snakes, and spiders, and now cultivating a mullen-stalk with induced tears—declaring it more trouble and responsibility than any undertaking in his life.
Tom loses his patience, accusing Jim of failing to appreciate the 'gaudier chances' for fame he is being offered, chances that are being wasted on him.
Feeling remorseful, Jim apologizes and promises to be more cooperative, after which Huck and Tom finally head to bed.

“Well, it always is when it’s done right. You got any rats around here?”
“No, sah, I hain’t seed none.”
“Well, we’ll get you some rats.”
“Why, Mars Tom, I doan’ want no rats. Dey’s de dadblamedest creturs to ’sturb a body, en rustle roun’ over ’im, en bite his feet, when he’s tryin’ to sleep, I ever see. No, sah, gimme g’yarter-snakes, ’f I’s got to have ’m, but doan’ gimme no rats; I hain’ got no use f’r um, skasely.”
“But, Jim, you got to have ’em—they all do. So don’t make no more fuss about it. Prisoners ain’t ever without rats. There ain’t no instance of it. And they train them, and pet them, and learn them tricks, and they get to be as sociable as flies. But you got to play music to them. You got anything to play music on?”
“I ain’ got nuffn but a coase comb en a piece o’ paper, en a juice-harp; but I reck’n dey wouldn’ take no stock in a juice-harp.”
“Yes they would. They don’t care what kind of music ’tis. A jews-harp’s plenty good enough for a rat. All animals like music—in a prison they dote on it. Specially, painful music; and you can’t get no other kind out of a jews-harp. It always interests them; they come out to see what’s the matter with you. Yes, you’re all right; you’re fixed very well. You want to set on your bed nights before you go to sleep, and early in the mornings, and play your jews-harp; play ‘The Last Link is Broken’—that’s the thing that’ll scoop a rat quicker ’n anything else; and when you’ve played about two minutes you’ll see all the rats, and the snakes, and spiders, and things begin to feel worried about you, and come. And they’ll just fairly swarm over you, and have a noble good time.”
“Yes, dey will, I reck’n, Mars Tom, but what kine er time is Jim havin’? Blest if I kin see de pint. But I’ll do it ef I got to. I reck’n I better keep de animals satisfied, en not have no trouble in de house.”
Tom waited to think it over, and see if there wasn’t nothing else; and pretty soon he says:
“Oh, there’s one thing I forgot. Could you raise a flower here, do you reckon?”
“I doan know but maybe I could, Mars Tom; but it’s tolable dark in heah, en I ain’ got no use f’r no flower, nohow, en she’d be a pow’ful sight o’ trouble.”
“Well, you try it, anyway. Some other prisoners has done it.”
“One er dem big cat-tail-lookin’ mullen-stalks would grow in heah, Mars Tom, I reck’n, but she wouldn’t be wuth half de trouble she’d coss.”
“Don’t you believe it. We’ll fetch you a little one and you plant it in the corner over there, and raise it. And don’t call it mullen, call it Pitchiola—that’s its right name when it’s in a prison. And you want to water it with your tears.”
“Why, I got plenty spring water, Mars Tom.”
“You don’t want spring water; you want to water it with your tears. It’s the way they always do.”
“Why, Mars Tom, I lay I kin raise one er dem mullen-stalks twyste wid spring water whiles another man’s a start’n one wid tears.”
“That ain’t the idea. You got to do it with tears.”
“She’ll die on my han’s, Mars Tom, she sholy will; kase I doan’ skasely ever cry.”
So Tom was stumped. But he studied it over, and then said Jim would have to worry along the best he could with an onion. He promised he would go to the nigger cabins and drop one, private, in Jim’s coffee-pot, in the morning. Jim said he would “jis’ ’s soon have tobacker in his coffee;” and found so much fault with it, and with the work and bother of raising the mullen, and jews-harping the rats, and petting and flattering up the snakes and spiders and things, on top of all the other work he had to do on pens, and inscriptions, and journals, and things, which made it more trouble and worry and responsibility to be a prisoner than anything he ever undertook, that Tom most lost all patience with him; and said he was just loadened down with more gaudier chances than a prisoner ever had in the world to make a name for himself, and yet he didn’t know enough to appreciate them, and they was just about wasted on him. So Jim he was sorry, and said he wouldn’t behave so no more, and then me and Tom shoved for bed.

“Rats? No, I ain’t seen none lately. Why?”

Tom grinned, his eyes lighting up with the mischief that always seemed to be brewing in his mind. “Because, Huck, you can’t have a proper prison escape without rats. That’s what the books say. I scratched my head, trying to remember if I’d ever seen a rat in the shed or around the yard. “I reckon we could find one if we tried. Maybe down by the woodpile.”

Tom nodded, satisfied. “Good. We’ll need at least two or three. And spiders, too. And snakes, if we can get ‘em.”

I shivered. “Snakes? What for?”

“Why, it’s part of the plan, Huck. The books say the prisoners always have snakes crawling around their cell, and they get used to ‘em, and it makes ‘em look more pitiful when folks come to visit. Besides, it’s more romantic.”

I didn’t know about that, but I wasn’t going to argue with Tom. He always had a way of making things sound like they was the only way to do ‘em, and I didn’t want to spoil his fun.

So we set about looking for rats and spiders and snakes. We found a couple of spiders under a log, and Tom caught them in a tin can. We didn’t have much luck with rats, but Tom said we could set a trap and try again in the morning. As for snakes, we saw a black racer slither off into the grass, but it was too quick for us.

When we got back to the shed, Tom started making a list of all the things we’d need for the escape. “We’ll need a rope ladder, made out of sheets. And we’ll have to bake it into a pie, so Jim can get it without the folks getting suspicious.”

I frowned. “How’s he going to eat a rope ladder baked in a pie?”

Tom looked at me like I was simple. “He ain’t supposed to eat it, Huck. He’s supposed to find it in the pie and use it to climb out the window.”

“Oh,” I said. “But there ain’t no window.”

Tom waved his hand. “That don’t matter. We’ll make one. Or we’ll pretend there is one. It’s all in the plan.”

I didn’t see how it was going to work, but I let Tom have his way. He was the one with the ideas, and I was just glad to be along for the ride.

That night, we snuck out to the shed where Jim was locked up. He was glad to see us, and we told him about the plan. He listened real careful, and when Tom finished, Jim shook his head.

“Mas’r Tom, I don’t know ‘bout all this. Seems like a heap of trouble for nothin’. Why can’t I just slip out the door when nobody’s lookin’?”

Tom looked shocked. “Jim, that ain’t the way it’s done. You got to do it right, or it don’t count. The books say so.”

Jim sighed, but he agreed to go along with it. He trusted Tom, and I reckon he trusted me, too.

The next few days was busy. We snuck around gathering things for the escape—old sheets, tin plates, candles, and anything else Tom said we needed. We even managed to catch a rat in the trap, and Tom was as proud as if he’d caught a mountain lion.

We baked the rope ladder into a pie, just like Tom said. It was a tight fit, but we managed it. When we brought it to Jim, he looked at it like he didn’t know whether to laugh or cry.

“Mas’r Tom, how I’m s’posed to get that out without Miss Watson seein’?”

Tom grinned. “That’s the beauty of it, Jim. You just wait till she’s gone, then you take it out. Easy as pie.”

Jim shook his head, but he took the pie and hid it under his blanket.

We kept working on the plan, adding more and more things as Tom thought of them. We dug a tunnel under the shed, even though there wasn’t much need for it. We wrote secret messages on tin plates and threw them out the window, even though there wasn’t nobody to read them. We even tried to train the rat to carry a message, but it just bit Tom and ran off.

Through it all, Tom was as happy as a lark. He said it was the best adventure he’d ever had, and I reckon he was right. It was a lot of work, but it was fun, too.

And all the while, Jim just waited, hoping that one day he’d be free. And I hoped so, too.

events.title: Rat-Trap Trouble and Creature Chaos
characters: Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps
detailed_summary: Huck and Tom procure a wire rat-trap and catch fifteen rats, which they place under Aunt Sally's bed.
While they are away collecting spiders, young Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps discovers the trap and opens it, releasing the rats.
Aunt Sally encounters the freed rats and reacts with great alarm, standing on her bed in distress.
Upon their return, Huck and Tom are disciplined by Aunt Sally with a hickory switch for the incident.
They spend another two hours catching a new batch of rats, though these are not of the same quality as the first.
The boys also gather an assortment of spiders, bugs, frogs, and caterpillars.
Their attempt to acquire a hornet's nest is thwarted by the family at home, resulting in the boys getting stung.
They apply 'allycumpain' to their stings for relief, though sitting remains uncomfortable.
Subsequently, they collect several dozen garter and house snakes, placing them in a bag in their room.
By suppertime, they reflect on their busy day, but later find the snakes have escaped due to an improperly tied sack.
The escaped snakes become a recurring nuisance in the house, frequently appearing in unexpected places like rafters, plates, or down people's necks.
Aunt Sally exhibits an extreme aversion to snakes, regardless of their harmlessness, and would flee dramatically at the sight of one.
Her reactions are so intense that she frightens her husband, who wishes snakes had never been created.
Even a week after all snakes were thought to be gone, Aunt Sally remained highly sensitive, startled by the slightest touch.
Tom remarks that such reactions are typical of all women, attributing it to their inherent nature.

events.text_segment:
In the morning we went up to the village and bought a wire rat-trap and fetched it down, and unstopped the best rat-hole, and in about an hour we had fifteen of the bulliest kind of ones; and then we took it and put it in a safe place under Aunt Sally’s bed. But while we was gone for spiders little Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps found it there, and opened the door of it to see if the rats would come out, and they did; and Aunt Sally she come in, and when we got back she was a-standing on top of the bed raising Cain, and the rats was doing what they could to keep off the dull times for her. So she took and dusted us both with the hickry, and we was as much as two hours catching another fifteen or sixteen, drat that meddlesome cub, and they warn’t the likeliest, nuther, because the first haul was the pick of the flock. I never see a likelier lot of rats than what that first haul was.
We got a splendid stock of sorted spiders, and bugs, and frogs, and caterpillars, and one thing or another; and we like to got a hornet’s nest, but we didn’t. The family was at home. We didn’t give it right up, but stayed with them as long as we could; because we allowed we’d tire them out or they’d got to tire us out, and they done it. Then we got allycumpain and rubbed on the places, and was pretty near all right again, but couldn’t set down convenient. And so we went for the snakes, and grabbed a couple of dozen garters and house-snakes, and put them in a bag, and put it in our room, and by that time it was supper-time, and a rattling good honest day’s work: and hungry?—oh, no, I reckon not! And there warn’t a blessed snake up there when we went back—we didn’t half tie the sack, and they worked out somehow, and left. But it didn’t matter much, because they was still on the premises somewheres. So we judged we could get some of them again. No, there warn’t no real scarcity of snakes about the house for a considerable spell. You’d see them dripping from the rafters and places every now and then; and they generly landed in your plate, or down the back of your neck, and most of the time where you didn’t want them. Well, they was handsome and striped, and there warn’t no harm in a million of them; but that never made no difference to Aunt Sally; she despised snakes, be the breed what they might, and she couldn’t stand them no way you could fix it; and every time one of them flopped down on her, it didn’t make no difference what she was doing, she would just lay that work down and light out. I never see such a woman. And you could hear her whoop to Jericho. You couldn’t get her to take a-holt of one of them with the tongs. And if she turned over and found one in bed she would scramble out and lift a howl that you would think the house was afire. She disturbed the old man so that he said he could most wish there hadn’t ever been no snakes created. Why, after every last snake had been gone clear out of the house for as much as a week Aunt Sally warn’t over it yet; she warn’t near over it; when she was setting thinking about something you could touch her on the back of her neck with a feather and she would jump right out of her stockings. It was very curious. But Tom said all women was just so. He said they was made that way for some reason or other.

Then we set to work to catch some more, for Tom said fifteen warn’t near enough, and besides, he allowed that if we had plenty, we could let some go every now and then, just to keep up the excitement and make it seem more like a real prison. So we hunted around the cellar and the smokehouse and the henhouse, and by dinner-time we had nigh onto two dozen, all alive and kicking, and making the awfullest racket you ever heard. Aunt Sally come in once and wanted to know what was making all that noise, but Tom he said it was only the kittens fighting, and she went off, grumbling about how she wished the cats would keep out of the house.

He said we mustn’t let them out all at once, but just a few at a time, so Jim could have the fun of catching them and taming them, the way prisoners always done in the books. Jim, he didn’t see much fun in it, but Tom said it was all in the regular line, and if he didn’t do it, it wouldn’t be right, and the escape wouldn’t work. Jim, he just groaned and said he reckoned he’d rather be a nigger than a prisoner, any day.

Then Tom said we must have some snakes, too, and spiders, and bugs, and all sorts of things that prisoners have to keep them company and make it more dreadful. So we went out in the woods and turned over logs and rocks, and pretty soon we had a sack full of garter-snakes and blacksnakes, and a bottle with a couple of big spiders in it, and some beetles and things. We took them up to the loft and let them out in the pen with the rats, and Tom said it was just splendid, and Jim would have the time of his life.

But that night, when Jim went to bed, he found the rats and snakes had got out and was all over the place, and he hollered and made such a fuss that Aunt Sally come running in with a candle, and when she saw the snakes and rats, she nearly fainted. Tom and me, we had to help catch them and put them back, and Aunt Sally said if she ever caught us with another rat or snake, she’d skin us alive. But Tom, he just laughed and said it was all part of the plan, and we mustn’t give up now.

So the next day, we fixed the pen better, and Tom said we must write some mysterious messages on the walls with blood, the way prisoners do, and make some pens out of old spoons and forks. We spent all afternoon scratching on the walls and making up messages about suffering and hope and freedom, and Tom said it was the best prison he ever saw. Jim, he just shook his head and said he hoped we’d get tired of it soon, but Tom said we was just getting started, and there was lots more to do before Jim could escape the right way.

events.title: Jim's Infested Cabin and Escape Preparations
detailed_summary: Huck and Tom are punished each time one of their snakes encounters Aunt Sally, who threatens worse if they re-infest the house.
Huck finds the effort of replacing the creatures more bothersome than the punishments themselves.
They manage to restock all the creatures, making Jim's cabin exceptionally lively.
Jim complains about the spiders, which he feels specifically target him, making his confinement uncomfortable.
He laments the lack of space in his bed due to rats, snakes, and the grindstone, finding sleep impossible because the creatures are always active in shifts.
One group of creatures would be active while the other rested, ensuring continuous disturbance for Jim.
If Jim tried to move to a new spot, the spiders would take the opportunity to bother him.
Jim declares that if he manages to escape, he would never consent to being a prisoner again, not even for a salary.
By the end of three weeks, all their preparations for Jim's escape are nearly finalized.
A shirt, intended for Jim, was delivered hidden inside a pie.
Whenever a rat bit Jim, he would use the opportunity to write in his journal while the 'ink' (presumably blood) was still fresh.
Pens had been fashioned, and inscriptions and other markings were carved onto the grindstone.
The leg of Jim's bed had been sawn in two, and Huck and Tom had eaten the sawdust, which caused them severe stomach-aches.
Huck describes the sawdust as the most indigestible he had ever encountered, an opinion shared by Tom.

We got a licking every time one of our snakes come in her way, and she allowed these lickings warn’t nothing to what she would do if we ever loaded up the place again with them. I didn’t mind the lickings, because they didn’t amount to nothing; but I minded the trouble we had to lay in another lot. But we got them laid in, and all the other things; and you never see a cabin as blithesome as Jim’s was when they’d all swarm out for music and go for him. Jim didn’t like the spiders, and the spiders didn’t like Jim; and so they’d lay for him, and make it mighty warm for him. And he said that between the rats and the snakes and the grindstone there warn’t no room in bed for him, skasely; and when there was, a body couldn’t sleep, it was so lively, and it was always lively, he said, because they never all slept at one time, but took turn about, so when the snakes was asleep the rats was on deck, and when the rats turned in the snakes come on watch, so he always had one gang under him, in his way, and t’other gang having a circus over him, and if he got up to hunt a new place the spiders would take a chance at him as he crossed over. He said if he ever got out this time he wouldn’t ever be a prisoner again, not for a salary.
Well, by the end of three weeks everything was in pretty good shape. The shirt was sent in early, in a pie, and every time a rat bit Jim he would get up and write a little in his journal whilst the ink was fresh; the pens was made, the inscriptions and so on was all carved on the grindstone; the bed-leg was sawed in two, and we had et up the sawdust, and it give us a most amazing stomach-ache. We reckoned we was all going to die, but didn’t. It was the most undigestible sawdust I ever see; and Tom said the same.

events.title: Impending Sale and Tom's "Nonymous" Letter Plan
detailed_summary: With the escape preparations complete, Huck, Tom, and especially Jim are exhausted.
Silas Phelps (the old man) had attempted to contact a non-existent plantation near Orleans to return Jim, but received no reply.
Consequently, Silas decides he will advertise Jim in newspapers in St. Louis and New Orleans.
The mention of St. Louis newspapers deeply worries Huck, who realizes their time to act is short.
Tom announces that it is now time to use 'nonnamous letters' as part of the escape plan.
Huck inquires about the nature of these letters.

Tom explains that 'nonnamous letters' are warnings sent to people to inform them that something significant is about to occur, citing historical precedents like a servant-girl warning about Louis XVI's planned escape.
He declares they will employ both methods: having a spy provide notice and sending anonymous letters.
Tom adds another element to the plan: the prisoner's mother traditionally swaps clothes with him, allowing him to escape in her attire while she remains, and they will incorporate this as well.

events.text_segment:
But as I was saying, we’d got all the work done now, at last; and we was all pretty much fagged out, too, but mainly Jim. The old man had wrote a couple of times to the plantation below Orleans to come and get their runaway nigger, but hadn’t got no answer, because there warn’t no such plantation; so he allowed he would advertise Jim in the St. Louis and New Orleans papers; and when he mentioned the St. Louis ones it give me the cold shivers, and I see we hadn’t no time to lose. So Tom said, now for the nonnamous letters.
“What’s them?” I says.
“Warnings to the people that something is up. Sometimes it’s done one way, sometimes another. But there’s always somebody spying around that gives notice to the governor of the castle. When Louis XVI. was going to light out of the Tooleries, a servant-girl done it. It’s a very good way, and so is the nonnamous letters. We’ll use them both. And it’s usual for the prisoner’s mother to change clothes with him, and she stays in, and he slides out in her clothes. We’ll do that, too.”

events.title: Debating and Implementing the "Nonymous" Letter Strategy
detailed_summary: Huck questions Tom's plan to warn anyone about the escape, believing it's the concerned parties' own responsibility to discover it.
Tom counters that the people involved (the Phelpses) are too unobservant and reliant on others, and without a warning, the escape would lack dramatic impact and be 'flat'.
Huck expresses his preference for a simple, unnoticed escape but ultimately agrees to follow Tom's more elaborate approach.
When Tom outlines the need for a servant-girl to deliver a letter, Huck asks who will play this role.
Tom assigns Huck the part, instructing him to sneak in at night and take a dress from a 'yaller girl'.
Huck expresses concern that this will cause trouble for the girl, who likely owns only that one dress.
Tom dismisses Huck's concern, stating the dress is needed for only fifteen minutes.
Huck suggests he could deliver the letter in his own clothes, but Tom insists on the servant-girl disguise for authenticity and 'principle', questioning Huck's lack thereof.
Huck reluctantly accepts the role and then asks who will impersonate Jim's mother.
Tom declares he will take on the role of Jim's mother and will procure a gown from Aunt Sally.
Huck points out that this would require Tom to stay behind in the cabin when he and Jim leave.

Tom reveals his workaround: he will stuff Jim's clothes with straw to create a decoy representing Jim's mother in disguise. Jim will then take the 'nigger woman's gown' from Tom and wear it, allowing all three of them to 'evade' together.
Tom explains that 'evasion' is the proper term for a stylish escape, particularly one made by a king or his son.

events.text_segment:
“But looky here, Tom, what do we want to warn anybody for that something’s up? Let them find it out for themselves—it’s their lookout.”
“Yes, I know; but you can’t depend on them. It’s the way they’ve acted from the very start—left us to do everything. They’re so confiding and mullet-headed they don’t take notice of nothing at all. So if we don’t give them notice there won’t be nobody nor nothing to interfere with us, and so after all our hard work and trouble this escape ’ll go off perfectly flat; won’t amount to nothing—won’t be nothing to it.”
“Well, as for me, Tom, that’s the way I’d like.”
“Shucks!” he says, and looked disgusted. So I says:
“But I ain’t going to make no complaint. Any way that suits you suits me. What you going to do about the servant-girl?”
“You’ll be her. You slide in, in the middle of the night, and hook that yaller girl’s frock.”
“Why, Tom, that’ll make trouble next morning; because, of course, she prob’bly hain’t got any but that one.”
“I know; but you don’t want it but fifteen minutes, to carry the nonnamous letter and shove it under the front door.”
“All right, then, I’ll do it; but I could carry it just as handy in my own togs.”
“You wouldn’t look like a servant-girl then, would you?”
“No, but there won’t be nobody to see what I look like, anyway.”
“That ain’t got nothing to do with it. The thing for us to do is just to do our duty, and not worry about whether anybody sees us do it or not. Hain’t you got no principle at all?”
“All right, I ain’t saying nothing; I’m the servant-girl. Who’s Jim’s mother?”
“I’m his mother. I’ll hook a gown from Aunt Sally.”
“Well, then, you’ll have to stay in the cabin when me and Jim leaves.”
“Not much. I’ll stuff Jim’s clothes full of straw and lay it on his bed to represent his mother in disguise, and Jim ’ll take the nigger woman’s gown off of me and wear it, and we’ll all evade together. When a prisoner of style escapes it’s called an evasion. It’s always called so when a king escapes, f’rinstance. And the same with a king’s son; it don’t make no difference whether he’s a natural one or an unnatural one.”

That’s mighty foolish, ain’t it? If anybody was to come up on us, or find out what we was about, it would be all up with us, don’t you see? I say, let’s keep still, and not breathe a word about it. Tom Sawyer looked at me with that old, mischievous twinkle in his eye. “Huck, you don’t understand. The thing of it is, if you don’t warn folks, there ain’t no excitement. events.title: Terrorizing the Phelpses with Anonymous Warnings
detailed_summary: Tom composes the first anonymous letter.
That night, Huck, wearing the stolen dress, delivers the letter by sliding it under the Phelpses' front door as per Tom's instructions.
The letter bears a cryptic message: 'Beware. Trouble is brewing. Keep a sharp lookout. UNKNOWN FRIEND.'
The following night, Tom draws a skull and crossbones using blood, and they affix this image to the front door.
On the subsequent night, they place another drawing, this time of a coffin, on the back door.
These warnings throw the Phelps family into a state of intense anxiety and fear.
Aunt Sally is particularly affected, becoming extremely jumpy and exclaiming 'ouch!' at any sudden noise, unexpected touch, or movement.
She develops a persistent fear that something is lurking behind her, causing her to frequently whirl around suddenly and cry out.
Her fear makes her dread going to bed, yet she is too scared to stay up.
Tom observes the family's escalating terror with considerable satisfaction, interpreting it as proof that his elaborate plan is functioning perfectly and being executed correctly.

So Tom he wrote the nonnamous letter, and I smouched the yaller wench’s frock that night, and put it on, and shoved it under the front door, the way Tom told me to. It said:
Beware. Trouble is brewing. Keep a sharp lookout. UNKNOWN FRIEND.
Next night we stuck a picture, which Tom drawed in blood, of a skull and crossbones on the front door; and next night another one of a coffin on the back door. I never see a family in such a sweat. They couldn’t a been worse scared if the place had a been full of ghosts laying for them behind everything and under the beds and shivering through the air. If a door banged, Aunt Sally she jumped and said “ouch!” if anything fell, she jumped and said “ouch!” if you happened to touch her, when she warn’t noticing, she done the same; she couldn’t face noway and be satisfied, because she allowed there was something behind her every time—so she was always a-whirling around sudden, and saying “ouch,” and before she’d got two-thirds around she’d whirl back again, and say it again; and she was afraid to go to bed, but she dasn’t set up. So the thing was working very well, Tom said; he said he never see a thing work more satisfactory. He said it showed it was done right.

events.title: The Final Elaborate Warning Letter
detailed_summary: Tom announces that it is time for the 'grand bulge,' the climactic phase of their scheme.
The very next morning, at dawn, they prepare another letter, initially uncertain about its delivery because they had overheard plans to post a guard at both doors throughout the night.
Tom descends the lightning rod to reconnoiter the situation.
He discovers the guard stationed at the back door is asleep.
Tom seizes the opportunity to stick the letter into the back of the sleeping guard's neck and then returns.
This final letter, also signed 'UNKNOWN FRIEND,' is crafted to appear as if written by a repentant member of a dangerous gang.
It warns that a 'desprate gang of cutthroats' from the Indian Territory intends to steal the runaway slave, Jim, that very night.
The letter explains that the previous frightening messages and symbols were a tactic by the gang to scare the family into staying indoors, thus not interfering with the theft.
The supposed author claims to have recently found religion and now wishes to betray the gang's 'helish design' and lead an honest life.
It provides specific details of the gang's plan: they will approach from the north, along the fence, precisely at midnight, using a false key to enter Jim's cabin.

The 'informant' states his assigned role is to blow a tin horn as a warning if any danger arises; however, he promises that instead, he will make a sound like a sheep ('BA') once the gang is inside Jim's cabin and will not blow the horn at all.
He instructs the family that, while the gang is occupied with loosening Jim's chains, they should quietly slip to the cabin, lock the gang inside, and then they can 'kill them at your leasure.'
The letter strongly advises them to follow these instructions exactly, warning that any deviation will make the gang suspicious and cause a 'whoop-jamboreehoo.'
The purported writer concludes by stating that he desires no reward, only the satisfaction of knowing he has done the right thing.

So he said, now for the grand bulge! So the very next morning at the streak of dawn we got another letter ready, and was wondering what we better do with it, because we heard them say at supper they was going to have a nigger on watch at both doors all night. Tom he went down the lightning-rod to spy around; and the nigger at the back door was asleep, and he stuck it in the back of his neck and come back. This letter said:
Don’t betray me, I wish to be your friend. There is a desprate gang of cutthroats from over in the Indian Territory going to steal your runaway nigger to-night, and they have been trying to scare you so as you will stay in the house and not bother them. I am one of the gang, but have got religgion and wish to quit it and lead an honest life again, and will betray the helish design. They will sneak down from northards, along the fence, at midnight exact, with a false key, and go in the nigger’s cabin to get him. I am to be off a piece and blow a tin horn if I see any danger; but stead of that I will BA like a sheep soon as they get in and not blow at all; then whilst they are getting his chains loose, you slip there and lock them in, and can kill them at your leasure. Don’t do anything but just the way I am telling you, if you do they will suspicion something and raise whoop-jamboreehoo. I do not wish any reward but to know I have done the right thing.
UNKNOWN FRIEND

events.title: Midnight Preparations and the Missing Butter
detailed_summary: Huck enjoyed a day of fishing and confirmed the raft was secure.
Upon returning home, he discovered the household in a state of extreme anxiety; he and Tom were sent to bed immediately after supper without any explanation for the adults' distress.
Unbeknownst to the adults, Huck and Tom were already aware of the "new letter" that was causing the commotion.
They covertly gathered a substantial lunch from the cellar and transported it to their room.
Awakening around 11:30 PM, Tom put on Aunt Sally's dress, which he had previously purloined, as they prepared to depart with their meal.
Tom abruptly realized that the butter was missing from their provisions.
Huck clarified that he had placed a piece of butter on some corn-pone earlier.
When Tom could not locate it, Huck suggested they could proceed without the butter.
Tom, however, insisted on having the butter and instructed Huck to retrieve it from the cellar.
Tom also outlined his intention to create a decoy of Jim's mother using straw stuffed into Jim's clothes and to emit a sheep-like sound as a signal upon Huck's return with the butter.

events.title: Caught by Aunt Sally and a Room Full of Farmers
detailed_summary: Following Tom's departure, Huck descended into the cellar to fetch the butter.
He successfully located the substantial piece of butter, which was as large as a fist, resting on the slab of corn-pone where he had originally placed it.
After extinguishing his light source, Huck began to ascend the stairs with extreme caution.
He managed to reach the main floor without incident, but at that moment, Aunt Sally appeared, carrying a candle.
Reacting quickly, Huck concealed the food items under his hat and placed the hat firmly on his head just as Aunt Sally caught sight of him.
Aunt Sally immediately began to question Huck about his reasons for being in the cellar at such a late hour.
Huck initially provided vague and unconvincing responses, claiming he was doing "nothing."
Aunt Sally, already agitated and suspicious due to a series of unusual recent events, pressed Huck (whom she still believed to be Tom) for a more truthful explanation.
Despite Huck's continued insistence that he had not been engaged in any improper activity, Aunt Sally remained unconvinced and suspicious.
She sternly ordered him to go into the sitting-room and wait there until she could deal with him, expressing her determination to uncover his mischief.
Upon entering the sitting-room, Huck was profoundly shocked to discover it occupied by approximately fifteen farmers, each of whom was armed with a gun.
He felt intensely ill and, overwhelmed by the sudden realization of how serious the situation had become, sank into a chair.

The farmers in the room appeared restless and uneasy; they were constantly fidgeting, taking their hats off and putting them back on, scratching their heads, and changing their seating positions, all while attempting to project an air of composure.
Huck, too, felt deeply uneasy but consciously made an effort to keep his own hat on his head.

So out he went, and down cellar went I. The hunk of butter, big as a person’s fist, was where I had left it, so I took up the slab of corn-pone with it on, and blowed out my light, and started up stairs very stealthy, and got up to the main floor all right, but here comes Aunt Sally with a candle, and I clapped the truck in my hat, and clapped my hat on my head, and the next second she see me; and she says:
“You been down cellar?”
“Yes’m.”
“What you been doing down there?”
“Noth’n.”
“Noth’n!”
“No’m.”
“Well, then, what possessed you to go down there this time of night?”
“I don’t know ’m.”
“You don’t know? Don’t answer me that way. Tom, I want to know what you been doing down there.”
“I hain’t been doing a single thing, Aunt Sally, I hope to gracious if I have.”
I reckoned she’d let me go now, and as a generl thing she would; but I s’pose there was so many strange things going on she was just in a sweat about every little thing that warn’t yard-stick straight; so she says, very decided:
“You just march into that setting-room and stay there till I come. You been up to something you no business to, and I lay I’ll find out what it is before I’m done with you.”
So she went away as I opened the door and walked into the setting-room. My, but there was a crowd there! Fifteen farmers, and every one of them had a gun. I was most powerful sick, and slunk to a chair and set down. They was setting around, some of them talking a little, in a low voice, and all of them fidgety and uneasy, but trying to look like they warn’t; but I knowed they was, because they was always taking off their hats, and putting them on, and scratching their heads, and changing their seats, and fumbling with their buttons. I warn’t easy myself, but I didn’t take my hat off, all the same.

I got into my old rags and my sugar-hogshead again, and was free and satisfied. But Tom Sawyer he hunted me up and said he was going to start a band of robbers, and I might join if I would go back to the widow and be respectable. So I went back.

The widow she cried over me, and called me a poor lost lamb, and she called me a lot of other names, too, but she never meant no harm by it. She put me in them new clothes again, and I couldn’t do nothing but sweat and sweat, and feel all cramped up. Well, then, the old thing commenced again. The widow rung a bell for supper, and you had to come to time. When you got to the table you couldn’t go right to eating, but you had to wait for the widow to tuck down her head and grumble a little over the victuals, though there warn’t really anything the matter with them—that is, nothing only everything was cooked by itself.

events.title: The Melting Butter Misunderstanding
detailed_summary: Huck anxiously wished for Aunt Sally to conclude her interrogation, even if it meant receiving a punishment, so he could quickly warn Tom about the dire escalation of their plans and the dangerous situation they had inadvertently created.
He recognized the urgent need to abandon their elaborate schemes and escape with Jim before the armed men lost their patience and acted.
When Aunt Sally finally arrived to question him, Huck was too disoriented and frightened to provide coherent answers.
The atmosphere in the room was thick with tension, as the assembled farmers grew increasingly agitated; some were eager to storm the cabin immediately, noting the late hour approaching midnight.
Others in the group urged caution and patience, preferring to wait for the pre-arranged sheep signal before taking action.
Amidst Aunt Sally's relentless questioning, Huck became progressively more terrified and overwhelmed by the circumstances.
The room grew increasingly hot, causing the butter concealed beneath Huck's hat to begin melting and trickling down his neck and behind his ears.
Just as one of the farmers declared his intention to enter the cabin immediately to capture the supposed desperadoes upon their arrival, Huck felt he was about to collapse.
At that critical moment, a noticeable streak of melted butter ran down Huck's forehead.
Aunt Sally witnessed this, turned deathly pale, and exclaimed in alarm that the child must be suffering from "brain-fever" and that his brains were literally "oozing out."
A commotion ensued as everyone rushed to see what was happening; Aunt Sally then snatched Huck's hat from his head, revealing the bread and the remnants of the butter.
Instantly relieved that Huck was not suffering from a serious illness, Aunt Sally embraced him tightly.

She expressed her profound gratitude that the situation was no worse, remarking on their recent string of misfortunes and how she had feared the worst upon seeing the substance on his head, thinking it resembled brains.
She gently chided Huck, saying she wouldn't have minded his trip to the cellar had she known it was merely for food.
Finally, she dismissed him, instructing him to go to bed immediately and not to let her see him again until the morning.

I did wish Aunt Sally would come, and get done with me, and lick me, if she wanted to, and let me get away and tell Tom how we’d overdone this thing, and what a thundering hornet’s-nest we’d got ourselves into, so we could stop fooling around straight off, and clear out with Jim before these rips got out of patience and come for us.
At last she come and begun to ask me questions, but I couldn’t answer them straight, I didn’t know which end of me was up; because these men was in such a fidget now that some was wanting to start right now and lay for them desperadoes, and saying it warn’t but a few minutes to midnight; and others was trying to get them to hold on and wait for the sheep-signal; and here was Aunty pegging away at the questions, and me a-shaking all over and ready to sink down in my tracks I was that scared; and the place getting hotter and hotter, and the butter beginning to melt and run down my neck and behind my ears; and pretty soon, when one of them says, “I’m for going and getting in the cabin first and right now, and catching them when they come,” I most dropped; and a streak of butter come a-trickling down my forehead, and Aunt Sally she see it, and turns white as a sheet, and says:
“For the land’s sake, what is the matter with the child? He’s got the brain-fever as shore as you’re born, and they’re oozing out!”
And everybody runs to see, and she snatches off my hat, and out comes the bread and what was left of the butter, and she grabbed me, and hugged me, and says:
“Oh, what a turn you did give me! and how glad and grateful I am it ain’t no worse; for luck’s against us, and it never rains but it pours, and when I see that truck I thought we’d lost you, for I knowed by the color and all it was just like your brains would be if—Dear, dear, whyd’nt you tell me that was what you’d been down there for, I wouldn’t a cared. Now cler out to bed, and don’t lemme see no more of you till morning!”

events.title: A Narrow Escape from the Cabin
detailed_summary: Huck moved with incredible speed, rushing upstairs, then quickly descending the lightning rod, and finally hurrying through the darkness towards the lean-to where Tom and Jim were waiting.

He was so overcome with anxiety that he found it difficult to speak, but he managed to quickly inform Tom that the house was filled with armed men and that they needed to make their escape without a moment's delay.
Upon hearing this news, Tom's eyes blazed with excitement rather than fear.
He expressed a thrill at the increased level of danger, even suggesting that if they had the chance to redo their plan, he could probably attract twice as many men.
Huck, focused on the immediate peril, urged Tom to hurry and asked for Jim's location.
Tom indicated that Jim was right beside them, fully dressed and prepared for their departure.
Just as they were about to give the pre-arranged sheep signal to indicate their readiness, they heard the distinct sound of men approaching the cabin door.
They then overheard the men fumbling with the padlock on the cabin and one man commenting that they had arrived too soon, as the "desperadoes" had not yet come and the door was still locked.

The same man instructed some members of his group to be locked inside the cabin, where they could lie in wait in the darkness and ambush their targets when they arrived; the rest of the group was told to scatter around the vicinity and listen for any sounds of approach.
The men subsequently entered the cabin but, due to the darkness, could not see Huck, Tom, and Jim, who were scrambling to hide; the men nearly trod on them in the process.

The trio successfully concealed themselves under the bed and then managed to escape through the hole in the wall, moving swiftly but silently. Jim went first, followed by Huck, and then Tom, in accordance with Tom's prior instructions.
Once they were all safely inside the lean-to, they could hear the sounds of men moving around very close by, just outside the structure.

events.text_segment:
I was up stairs in a second, and down the lightning-rod in another one, and shinning through the dark for the lean-to. I couldn’t hardly get my words out, I was so anxious; but I told Tom as quick as I could we must jump for it now, and not a minute to lose—the house full of men, yonder, with guns!
His eyes just blazed; and he says:
“No!—is that so? Ain’t it bully! Why, Huck, if it was to do over again, I bet I could fetch two hundred! If we could put it off till—”
“Hurry! hurry!” I says. “Where’s Jim?”
“Right at your elbow; if you reach out your arm you can touch him. He’s dressed, and everything’s ready. Now we’ll slide out and give the sheep-signal.”
But then we heard the tramp of men coming to the door, and heard them begin to fumble with the pad-lock, and heard a man say:
“I told you we’d be too soon; they haven’t come—the door is locked. Here, I’ll lock some of you into the cabin, and you lay for ’em in the dark and kill ’em when they come; and the rest scatter around a piece, and listen if you can hear ’em coming.”
So in they come, but couldn’t see us in the dark, and most trod on us whilst we was hustling to get under the bed. But we got under all right, and out through the hole, swift but soft—Jim first, me next, and Tom last, which was according to Tom’s orders. Now we was in the lean-to, and heard trampings close by outside.

events.title: The Chase and Freedom on the Raft
detailed_summary: Inside the lean-to, Tom positioned himself at the door and peered through a crack, but the darkness outside was too profound for him to discern anything.
He whispered to Huck and Jim that he would listen intently for the men's footsteps to recede and would give them a nudge when it was safe for Jim to slip out first, with Tom himself exiting last.
After a tense period of listening, during which they could hear the continuous sound of footsteps scraping around outside, Tom finally gave the signal.
They emerged from the lean-to, moving with extreme caution, holding their breath, and making not the slightest noise as they proceeded in single file towards the fence.
Huck and Jim successfully made it over the fence.
However, Tom's trousers became snagged on a splinter protruding from the top rail of the fence.
Hearing the sound of approaching footsteps, Tom was forced to pull himself free quickly, which caused the splinter to snap with a distinct noise.
As Tom landed on the other side of the fence and began to run, someone from the pursuing party shouted, demanding they identify themselves or face being shot.
The trio did not respond but instead increased their pace, running as fast as they possibly could.
A rush of pursuers followed, accompanied by the sharp reports of gunfire, and bullets whizzed alarmingly close to them.
They heard their pursuers shouting that the fugitives had broken for the river and calling for the dogs to be turned loose to aid in the chase.
The pursuing men, encumbered by boots and making a great deal of noise by shouting, inadvertently gave Huck, Tom, and Jim an advantage, as the three fugitives were barefoot and moved silently.
They found themselves on the path leading to the mill and, when the pursuers drew near, they deftly dodged into the bushes, allowed the men to pass by, and then quietly fell in behind them.
The dogs, which had initially been kept confined so as not to scare off the supposed robbers, were now released and rushed towards the sounds of the commotion, barking loudly.

However, these were their own dogs; upon recognizing Huck, Tom, and Jim, and realizing there was no real excitement or threat to engage them, the dogs merely offered a brief, familiar greeting before tearing off towards the ongoing sounds of shouting and clattering from the pursuing men.
The trio then quickly made their way upstream again, hurrying along after their dogs until they were nearly at the mill.

From there, they struck up through the bush to the location where Huck's canoe was tied, quickly hopped in, and paddled with all their might towards the middle of the river, taking care to make no more noise than was absolutely necessary.
Once in the current, they proceeded more easily and comfortably towards the island where Huck's raft was hidden.
They could hear the sounds of the men yelling and the dogs barking on the riverbank, but these noises gradually grew dimmer and eventually died out as they moved further away.
Upon stepping onto the raft, Huck triumphantly declared to Jim that he was a free man once again and expressed his belief that Jim would never be a slave anymore.

Jim enthusiastically agreed, praising the escape plan as beautifully conceived and executed, and marveling at its intricate and splendid nature, claiming no one could devise a more wonderfully complicated scheme.
