So we crept to the door, and Tom stopped us there and put his eye to the crack, but couldn’t make out nothing, it was so dark; and whispered and said he would listen for the steps to get further, and when he nudged us Jim must glide out first, and him last. So he set his ear to the crack and listened, and listened, and listened, and the steps a-scraping around out there all the time; and at last he nudged us, and we slid out, and stooped down, not breathing, and not making the least noise, and slipped stealthy towards the fence in Injun file, and got to it all right, and me and Jim over it; but Tom’s britches catched fast on a splinter on the top rail, and then he hear the steps coming, so he had to pull loose, which snapped the splinter and made a noise; and as he dropped in our tracks and started somebody sings out:
“Who’s that? Answer, or I’ll shoot!”
But we didn’t answer; we just unfurled our heels and shoved. Then there was a rush, and a bang, bang, bang! and the bullets fairly whizzed around us! We heard them sing out:
“Here they are! They’ve broke for the river! After ’em, boys, and turn loose the dogs!”
So here they come, full tilt. We could hear them because they wore boots and yelled, but we didn’t wear no boots and didn’t yell. We was in the path to the mill; and when they got pretty close on to us we dodged into the bush and let them go by, and then dropped in behind them. They’d had all the dogs shut up, so they wouldn’t scare off the robbers; but by this time somebody had let them loose, and here they come, making powwow enough for a million; but they was our dogs; so we stopped in our tracks till they catched up; and when they see it warn’t nobody but us, and no excitement to offer them, they only just said howdy, and tore right ahead towards the shouting and clattering; and then we up-steam again, and whizzed along after them till we was nearly to the mill, and then struck up through the bush to where my canoe was tied, and hopped in and pulled for dear life towards the middle of the river, but didn’t make no more noise than we was obleeged to. Then we struck out, easy and comfortable, for the island where my raft was; and we could hear them yelling and barking at each other all up and down the bank, till we was so far away the sounds got dim and died out. And when we stepped onto the raft I says:
“Now, old Jim, you’re a free man again, and I bet you won’t ever be a slave no more.”
“En a mighty good job it wuz, too, Huck. It ’uz planned beautiful, en it ’uz done beautiful; en dey ain’t nobody kin git up a plan dat’s mo’ mixed-up en splendid den what dat one wuz.”

And then we up steam again, and whizzed along after them till we was nearly to the mill; then struck up through the bush to where my canoe was tied, and hopped in, and pulled for dear life towards the middle of the river, but didn’t make no more noise than we was obliged to. Then we struck out, easy and comfortable, for the island where my raft was, and we could hear them yelling and barking at each other all up and down the bank, till we was so far away the sounds got dim and died out; and when we stepped onto the raft I says:

"Now, old Jim, you’re a free man again, and I bet you won’t ever be a slave no more."

"En a mighty good job it wuz, too, Huck; it ’uz planned beautiful, en it’s done beautiful; en dey ain’t nobody kin git up a plan dat’s mo’ mixed-up en splendid den what dat one wuz."

events.title: Tom's Wound and Jim's Noble Stand
detailed_summary: While everyone was relieved by their successful escape, Tom was paradoxically the most elated because he had sustained a bullet wound in the calf of his leg during the chase.
When Huck and Jim learned about Tom's injury, their initial feelings of triumph were tempered with concern.
Tom was clearly in considerable pain and his leg was bleeding, so they helped him into the wigwam on the raft to tend to his wound.
They tore strips from one of the duke's old shirts to use as makeshift bandages.
Tom, however, still caught up in the romantic thrill of the "evasion," insisted on bandaging his own leg and urged them to set the raft loose immediately and continue their flight.

He boasted about the "elegant" manner in which they had accomplished their escape and even launched into a fantastical monologue about how they would have handled historical figures like Louis XVI, implying they would have managed his escape far more effectively.
While Tom was exulting in his injury and their adventure, Huck and Jim quietly conferred with each other.
After a moment of thoughtful silence, Huck prompted Jim to articulate what was on his mind.

Jim then delivered a profound moral statement, arguing that if their roles were reversed—if Tom were the one being set free and one of his companions (Huck or Jim) had been shot—Tom would never abandon his injured friend to save himself without first securing medical attention.
Jim rhetorically questioned if such selfish behavior was characteristic of Tom Sawyer, confidently asserting that Tom would indeed prioritize the well-being of his friends.
Therefore, Jim firmly declared that he would not budge from their current location without a doctor for Tom, even if it meant waiting for forty years.
Huck deeply recognized and admired the inherent goodness, loyalty, and selflessness in Jim's principled stand, internally acknowledging that Jim was "white inside."
Huck had anticipated that Jim would react in this noble way, and with Jim's resolute decision, Huck felt a sense of rightness and immediately informed Tom that he was going to fetch a doctor.

We was all glad as we could be, but Tom was the gladdest of all because he had a bullet in the calf of his leg.
When me and Jim heard that we didn’t feel so brash as what we did before. It was hurting him considerable, and bleeding; so we laid him in the wigwam and tore up one of the duke’s shirts for to bandage him, but he says:
“Gimme the rags; I can do it myself. Don’t stop now; don’t fool around here, and the evasion booming along so handsome; man the sweeps, and set her loose! Boys, we done it elegant!—’deed we did. I wish we’d a had the handling of Louis XVI., there wouldn’t a been no ‘Son of Saint Louis, ascend to heaven!’ wrote down in his biography; no, sir, we’d a whooped him over the border—that’s what we’d a done with him—and done it just as slick as nothing at all, too. Man the sweeps—man the sweeps!”
But me and Jim was consulting—and thinking. And after we’d thought a minute, I says:
“Say it, Jim.”
So he says:
“Well, den, dis is de way it look to me, Huck. Ef it wuz him dat ’uz bein’ sot free, en one er de boys wuz to git shot, would he say, ‘Go on en save me, nemmine ’bout a doctor f’r to save dis one?’ Is dat like Mars Tom Sawyer? Would he say dat? You bet he wouldn’t! Well, den, is Jim gywne to say it? No, sah—I doan’ budge a step out’n dis place ’dout a doctor; not if it’s forty year!”
I knowed he was white inside, and I reckoned he’d say what he did say—so it was all right now, and I told Tom I was a-going for a doctor.

events.title: Tom's Theatrical Plan for Fetching the Doctor
detailed_summary: Tom protested vigorously against the idea of fetching a doctor, but Huck and Jim remained steadfast in their decision, refusing to yield.
In his frustration, Tom even threatened to crawl out of the wigwam and set the raft adrift himself, but Huck and Jim prevented him from doing so.
Tom then delivered a tirade, expressing his displeasure, but his angry words had no impact on their resolve.
Seeing that Huck was already preparing the canoe for the journey, Tom reluctantly accepted their decision to seek medical help.
He then proceeded to give Huck a series of elaborate and highly theatrical instructions on how to fetch the doctor, drawing heavily on conventions from adventure stories and dime novels.

These detailed instructions included specific actions such as going to the doctor's house, shutting the door behind him, blindfolding the doctor tightly and securely, and making him swear a solemn oath to remain as silent as the grave about the entire affair.
Huck was also instructed to place a purse full of gold in the doctor's hand.
Following this, Huck was to lead the blindfolded doctor on a convoluted route through back alleys and various dark, out-of-the-way places.
He was then to transport the doctor to the raft by canoe, taking a deliberately roundabout path amongst the islands to further obscure their location.

Upon arrival at the raft, Huck was to search the doctor thoroughly and confiscate any chalk he might be carrying, not returning it until they had safely delivered the doctor back to the village. This precaution was to prevent the doctor from marking the raft's location for later discovery.
Tom concluded his instructions by explaining that this elaborate procedure was "the way they all do" in such clandestine operations described in his beloved books.
Huck agreed to follow Tom's complicated plan and then departed in the canoe.
It was arranged that Jim would conceal himself in the woods near the raft when he saw the doctor approaching and remain hidden until after the doctor had treated Tom and left again.

So when he sees me getting the canoe ready, he says:
“Well, then, if you’re bound to go, I’ll tell you the way to do when you get to the village. Shut the door and blindfold the doctor tight and fast, and make him swear to be silent as the grave, and put a purse full of gold in his hand, and then take and lead him all around the back alleys and everywheres in the dark, and then fetch him here in the canoe, in a roundabout way amongst the islands, and search him and take his chalk away from him, and don’t give it back to him till you get him back to the village, or else he will chalk this raft so he can find it again. It’s the way they all do.”
So I said I would, and left, and Jim was to hide in the woods when he see the doctor coming till he was gone again.

events.title: Huck's Deception and the Doctor's Departure for Tom
detailed_summary: Huck awakens an elderly doctor, presenting himself as the brother of a boy named 'Sid' (actually Tom Sawyer).
He concocts a story about 'Sid' accidentally shooting himself in the leg on Spanish Island during a supposed hunting trip, emphasizing the need for secrecy to surprise their 'folks,' the Phelpses.
The doctor, though expressing some skepticism about the 'dream' that supposedly caused the gunshot, agrees to help and prepares his lantern and saddle-bags.
When the doctor sees Huck's small canoe, he expresses concern about its safety for two people.
Huck attempts to reassure him by claiming it previously carried three people and guns, a slip he quickly tries to cover.
The doctor tests the canoe, remains unconvinced, and decides to look for a larger one, but finds others locked.
He ultimately takes Huck's canoe alone, instructing Huck to either wait, search for another canoe, or go home to prepare for the 'surprise.'
Huck chooses to wait and provides the doctor with directions to the raft where Tom is located.

events.text_segment:
The doctor was an old man; a very nice, kind-looking old man when I got him up. I told him me and my brother was over on Spanish Island hunting yesterday afternoon, and camped on a piece of a raft we found, and about midnight he must a kicked his gun in his dreams, for it went off and shot him in the leg, and we wanted him to go over there and fix it and not say nothing about it, nor let anybody know, because we wanted to come home this evening and surprise the folks.
“Who is your folks?” he says.
“The Phelpses, down yonder.”
“Oh,” he says. And after a minute, he says:
“How’d you say he got shot?”
“He had a dream,” I says, “and it shot him.”
“Singular dream,” he says.
So he lit up his lantern, and got his saddle-bags, and we started. But when he sees the canoe he didn’t like the look of her—said she was big enough for one, but didn’t look pretty safe for two. I says:
“Oh, you needn’t be afeard, sir, she carried the three of us easy enough.”
“What three?”
“Why, me and Sid, and—and—and the guns; that’s what I mean.”
“Oh,” he says.
But he put his foot on the gunnel and rocked her, and shook his head, and said he reckoned he’d look around for a bigger one. But they was all locked and chained; so he took my canoe, and said for me to wait till he come back, or I could hunt around further, or maybe I better go down home and get them ready for the surprise if I wanted to. But I said I didn’t; so I told him just how to find the raft, and then he started.

events.title: Huck's Anxious Planning and Belated Awakening
detailed_summary: Immediately after the doctor departs, Huck begins to worry about the potential consequences if Tom's leg injury requires extended care.
He fears the doctor might reveal their situation prematurely, thus 'letting the cat out of the bag.'
To prevent this, Huck devises a contingency plan: if the doctor indicates a need for further visits, Huck will swim to the raft.
His plan involves forcibly detaining the doctor, keeping him on the raft downriver until Tom no longer needs medical attention, and then compensating him before releasing him.
Having formulated this drastic plan, Huck seeks rest in a lumber-pile.
He oversleeps significantly, waking to find the sun high in the sky, indicating much time has passed.
Rushing to the doctor's house, Huck learns that the doctor had left sometime during the night and has not yet returned.

events.title: Unexpected Encounter with Uncle Silas and a New Fabrication
detailed_summary: Feeling that the doctor's prolonged absence bodes ill for Tom, Huck decides to head for the island immediately.
As he sets off, he unexpectedly collides with Uncle Silas.
Caught off guard, Huck, who is known to the Phelpses as 'Tom Sawyer,' quickly invents a new lie to explain his and 'Sid's' (the real Tom Sawyer's) absence.
He claims that he and 'Sid' were out hunting the runaway slave, Jim.
Huck elaborates that they followed the posse, lost them, then pursued sounds on the water by canoe, eventually tying up and falling asleep.

He further states they only woke up about an hour ago, paddled back to hear news, and that 'Sid' is currently at the post-office while he (Huck as 'Tom') is looking for food before they both head home.

events.text_segment:
Well, thinks I, that looks powerful bad for Tom, and I’ll dig out for the island right off. So away I shoved, and turned the corner, and nearly rammed my head into Uncle Silas’s stomach! He says:
“Why, Tom! Where you been all this time, you rascal?”
“I hain’t been nowheres,” I says, “only just hunting for the runaway nigger—me and Sid.”
“Why, where ever did you go?” he says. “Your aunt’s been mighty uneasy.”
“She needn’t,” I says, “because we was all right. We followed the men and the dogs, but they outrun us, and we lost them; but we thought we heard them on the water, so we got a canoe and took out after them and crossed over, but couldn’t find nothing of them; so we cruised along up-shore till we got kind of tired and beat out; and tied up the canoe and went to sleep, and never waked up till about an hour ago; then we paddled over here to hear the news, and Sid’s at the post-office to see what he can hear, and I’m a-branching out to get something to eat for us, and then we’re going home.”

events.title: Neighbors' Speculation on Jim's Escape and Aunt Sally's Mounting Hysteria
detailed_summary: The Phelps' house is crowded with local farmers and their wives, all animatedly discussing Jim's escape and the bizarre items found in his cabin.
Old Mrs. Hotchkiss dominates the conversation, vehemently arguing that Jim must have been insane, citing the strange carvings on the grindstone as primary evidence.
Other women, like Mrs. Damrell and Sister Utterback, express bewilderment over the purpose of a rag ladder.
Brer Penrod and others question how the heavy grindstone was moved into the cabin and who dug the hole.
The discussion leads to a consensus that Jim must have had considerable assistance, with speculation on the number of helpers ranging from a dozen to forty.
They marvel at the tedious creation of case-knife saws, the effort to saw off a bed-leg, and the presence of a straw effigy of Jim.
Brother Marples highlights a shirt covered in what he calls 'secret African writ'n' done in blood, expressing a desire to have it deciphered.

Aunt Sally interjects, detailing a long list of stolen household items, from a shirt and sheet to flour, candles, spoons, and even her new calico dress, emphasizing that these thefts occurred despite her family's constant vigilance.
She concludes that spirits must have been involved in Jim's escape, as their highly skilled dogs never even found a trail, challenging anyone to explain it.
The neighbors react with various expressions of shock and fear at the audacity and mystery of the events.
Aunt Sally recounts her extreme fear the previous night, admitting she was so agitated she even locked her 'two poor boys' (Huck as 'Tom', and Tom Sawyer as 'Sid') in their room.
As she finishes speaking and her gaze falls upon Huck, he, realizing the implication of her statement for his earlier fabricated alibi, quietly excuses himself and leaves the room.

And the place was plum full of farmers and farmers’ wives, to dinner; and such another clack a body never heard. Old Mrs. Hotchkiss was the worst; her tongue was a-going all the time. She says:
“Well, Sister Phelps, I’ve ransacked that-air cabin over, an’ I b’lieve the nigger was crazy. I says to Sister Damrell—didn’t I, Sister Damrell?—s’I, he’s crazy, s’I—them’s the very words I said. You all hearn me: he’s crazy, s’I; everything shows it, s’I. Look at that-air grindstone, s’I; want to tell me’t any cretur ’t’s in his right mind ’s a goin’ to scrabble all them crazy things onto a grindstone, s’I? Here sich ’n’ sich a person busted his heart; ’n’ here so ’n’ so pegged along for thirty-seven year, ’n’ all that—natcherl son o’ Louis somebody, ’n’ sich everlast’n rubbage. He’s plumb crazy, s’I; it’s what I says in the fust place, it’s what I says in the middle, ’n’ it’s what I says last ’n’ all the time—the nigger’s crazy—crazy ’s Nebokoodneezer, s’I.”
“An’ look at that-air ladder made out’n rags, Sister Hotchkiss,” says old Mrs. Damrell; “what in the name o’ goodness could he ever want of—”
“The very words I was a-sayin’ no longer ago th’n this minute to Sister Utterback, ’n’ she’ll tell you so herself. Sh-she, look at that-air rag ladder, sh-she; ’n’ s’I, yes, look at it, s’I—what could he a-wanted of it, s’I. Sh-she, Sister Hotchkiss, sh-she—”
“But how in the nation’d they ever git that grindstone in there, anyway? ’n’ who dug that-air hole? ’n’ who—”
“My very words, Brer Penrod! I was a-sayin’—pass that-air sasser o’ m’lasses, won’t ye?—I was a-sayin’ to Sister Dunlap, jist this minute, how did they git that grindstone in there, s’I. Without help, mind you—’thout help! Thar’s wher ’tis. Don’t tell me, s’I; there wuz help, s’I; ’n’ ther’ wuz a plenty help, too, s’I; ther’s ben a dozen a-helpin’ that nigger, ’n’ I lay I’d skin every last nigger on this place but I’d find out who done it, s’I; ’n’ moreover, s’I—”
“A dozen says you!—forty couldn’t a done every thing that’s been done. Look at them case-knife saws and things, how tedious they’ve been made; look at that bed-leg sawed off with ’m, a week’s work for six men; look at that nigger made out’n straw on the bed; and look at—”
“You may well say it, Brer Hightower! It’s jist as I was a-sayin’ to Brer Phelps, his own self. S’e, what do you think of it, Sister Hotchkiss, s’e? Think o’ what, Brer Phelps, s’I? Think o’ that bed-leg sawed off that a way, s’e? think of it, s’I? I lay it never sawed itself off, s’I—somebody sawed it, s’I; that’s my opinion, take it or leave it, it mayn’t be no ’count, s’I, but sich as ’t is, it’s my opinion, s’I, ’n’ if any body k’n start a better one, s’I, let him do it, s’I, that’s all. I says to Sister Dunlap, s’I—”
“Why, dog my cats, they must a ben a house-full o’ niggers in there every night for four weeks to a done all that work, Sister Phelps. Look at that shirt—every last inch of it kivered over with secret African writ’n done with blood! Must a ben a raft uv ’m at it right along, all the time, amost. Why, I’d give two dollars to have it read to me; ’n’ as for the niggers that wrote it, I ’low I’d take ’n’ lash ’m t’ll—”
“People to help him, Brother Marples! Well, I reckon you’d think so if you’d a been in this house for a while back. Why, they’ve stole everything they could lay their hands on—and we a-watching all the time, mind you. They stole that shirt right off o’ the line! and as for that sheet they made the rag ladder out of, ther’ ain’t no telling how many times they didn’t steal that; and flour, and candles, and candlesticks, and spoons, and the old warming-pan, and most a thousand things that I disremember now, and my new calico dress; and me and Silas and my Sid and Tom on the constant watch day and night, as I was a-telling you, and not a one of us could catch hide nor hair nor sight nor sound of them; and here at the last minute, lo and behold you, they slides right in under our noses and fools us, and not only fools us but the Injun Territory robbers too, and actuly gets away with that nigger safe and sound, and that with sixteen men and twenty-two dogs right on their very heels at that very time! I tell you, it just bangs anything I ever heard of. Why, sperits couldn’t a done better and been no smarter. And I reckon they must a been sperits—because, you know our dogs, and ther’ ain’t no better; well, them dogs never even got on the track of ’m once! You explain that to me if you can!—any of you!”
“Well, it does beat—”
“Laws alive, I never—”
“So help me, I wouldn’t a be—”
“House-thieves as well as—”
“Goodnessgracioussakes, I’d a ben afeard to live in sich a—”
“’Fraid to live!—why, I was that scared I dasn’t hardly go to bed, or get up, or lay down, or set down, Sister Ridgeway. Why, they’d steal the very—why, goodness sakes, you can guess what kind of a fluster I was in by the time midnight come last night. I hope to gracious if I warn’t afraid they’d steal some o’ the family! I was just to that pass I didn’t have no reasoning faculties no more. It looks foolish enough now, in the daytime; but I says to myself, there’s my two poor boys asleep, ’way up stairs in that lonesome room, and I declare to goodness I was that uneasy ’t I crep’ up there and locked ’em in! I did. And anybody would. Because, you know, when you get scared that way, and it keeps running on, and getting worse and worse all the time, and your wits gets to addling, and you get to doing all sorts o’ wild things, and by-and-by you think to yourself, spos’n I was a boy, and was away up there, and the door ain’t locked, and you—” She stopped, looking kind of wondering, and then she turned her head around slow, and when her eye lit on me—I got up and took a walk.

There was the clatter of knives and forks, the rattle of dishes, and the hum of voices all mixed together, so that a body could hardly hear himself think. The tables was loaded down with all sorts of good things—fried chicken, ham, greens, corn bread, and pies of every kind you could name. The farmers and their wives was dressed in their Sunday best, and the children was running about, laughing and playing, their faces shining with excitement and the promise of sweet things to come.

I slipped in as quiet as I could, trying not to draw any attention, but it warn’t no use. Everybody was friendly, and before I knew it, a big, motherly woman had me by the arm and was leading me to a seat at the table. She piled my plate high with food and told me to eat my fill, and I warn’t about to argue with her. I set to work, and I reckon I never tasted anything so good in all my life.

While I was eating, I listened to the talk around me. The men was talking about crops and the price of corn, and the women was gossiping about their neighbors and the preacher’s new wife. Every now and then, somebody would ask me who I was and where I come from, but I just said I was traveling through and didn’t have no folks around these parts. That seemed to satisfy them, and they went back to their talking and laughing.

After dinner, everybody moved out onto the porch or into the yard, and the men lit their pipes and the women fanned themselves with their bonnets. The children played tag and hide-and-seek among the trees, and the whole place was alive with the sound of voices and laughter. I felt right at home, and for a little while, I almost forgot about all the trouble I was in.

But it warn’t long before I started to get uneasy. I kept thinking about Jim, hiding out on the island, and I knew I couldn’t stay here too long. I slipped away from the crowd and made my way back down to the river, keeping to the shadows so nobody would see me. When I got to the water’s edge, I looked back at the house, all lit up and full of people, and I felt a pang of longing. But I knew I couldn’t stay. I had to get back to Jim and figure out what we was going to do next.

When I got back to the island, Jim was waiting for me, his eyes wide with worry. I told him about the dinner and all the people, and he listened close, nodding his head. We talked about what we should do, and finally decided we’d have to move on. It warn’t safe to stay so close to town, not with all them people around.

So that night, we packed up our things and set out down the river again, drifting with the current and keeping to the shadows. The moon was bright, and the water was smooth as glass. We didn’t say much, just listened to the sounds of the night and the splash of the oars. I felt a little sad, leaving behind the warmth and comfort of that house, but I knew we was doing the right thing.

As we floated down the river, I thought about all the people I’d met, and how different their lives was from mine and Jim’s. They had homes and families and a place in the world, while we was just drifting, trying to stay one step ahead of trouble. But I reckoned that was the way things had to be, at least for now.

We traveled on through the night, and by morning, we was far away from the town and the people. The river was wide and quiet, and the only sound was the call of a bird in the trees. Jim and me sat in the bottom of the raft, watching the sun come up over the water, and for a little while, everything seemed peaceful and right.

But I knew it wouldn’t last. There was always something waiting around the bend, some new danger or trouble. But I reckoned we could handle it, as long as we stuck together and kept our wits about us. And so we floated on, down the big river, into whatever adventures lay ahead.

events.title: Huck's Elaborate Alibi and Aunt Sally's Renewed Anxiety for 'Sid'
detailed_summary: Having slipped away, Huck formulates an explanation for why he and 'Sid' were not in their locked room that morning.
He later returns and tells Aunt Sally that the noise and shooting from Jim's escape woke them.
He claims that, finding their door locked but wanting to see the excitement, they climbed down the lightning rod, both sustaining minor injuries in the process, and resolved never to try it again.
Huck then recounts the fabricated story he had earlier told Uncle Silas about their supposed pursuit of the runaway slave.
Aunt Sally, mollified, forgives them, attributing their actions to the typical harum-scarum nature of boys.
She expresses relief that no real harm came of it and decides to be grateful they are alive and well rather than dwelling on the past.
After a moment of thought, Aunt Sally suddenly realizes with concern that it is almost night and 'Sid' (Tom Sawyer) has still not returned, questioning his whereabouts.

Says I to myself, I can explain better how we come to not be in that room this morning if I go out to one side and study over it a little. So I done it. But I dasn’t go fur, or she’d a sent for me. And when it was late in the day the people all went, and then I come in and told her the noise and shooting waked up me and “Sid,” and the door was locked, and we wanted to see the fun, so we went down the lightning-rod, and both of us got hurt a little, and we didn’t never want to try that no more. And then I went on and told her all what I told Uncle Silas before; and then she said she’d forgive us, and maybe it was all right enough anyway, and about what a body might expect of boys, for all boys was a pretty harum-scarum lot as fur as she could see; and so, as long as no harm hadn’t come of it, she judged she better put in her time being grateful we was alive and well and she had us still, stead of fretting over what was past and done. So then she kissed me, and patted me on the head, and dropped into a kind of a brown study; and pretty soon jumps up, and says:
“Why, lawsamercy, it’s most night, and Sid not come yet! What has become of that boy?”

Says I to myself, I can explain better how we come to not be in that room this morning if I go out to one side and study over it a little. So I done it; but I dasn’t go fur, or she’d see me. So I done it, and then I stuck out behind a corner of the wood-pile, and studied over it, and then I says to myself, if it was the best thing to do, or not? I couldn’t tell. But I reckoned I’d got to do it, and so I done it. 

It warn’t no use to waste any more time, so I come up to the door, and Aunt Sally she was a-standing there, looking out. She says:

"You been out to see the excitement, have you?"

I says:

"Yes’m."

She says:

"What kept you so long?"

I couldn’t think of anything to say, so I just stood there and stared down at my toes. She says:

"Well, you can’t get around it now, you got to tell me what you’ve been doing, and where you’ve been."

So I says:

"We heard the noise, and we all woke up, and Sid wanted to see what was the matter, and so we slipped out and down the lightning-rod, and been hunting around ever since, trying to find out."

She grabbed me and hugged me tight, and says:

"Oh, I’m so glad you’re safe and sound! Boys will be boys, I reckon. I’m just going to be thankful you’re alive and well, and not worry about what’s past."

She kissed me, and patted me on the head, and then she set down and fell to thinking. By and by she jumps up, and says:

"Why, where’s Sid?"

Before I could answer, she run to the door and looked out, and then she put her hand to her mouth and says:

"It’s most night, and Sid ain’t come yet! Where could he be?"

events.title: Growing Concern for 'Sid,' Aunt Sally's Distress, and Huck's Guilt
detailed_summary: Huck quickly offers to go to town and find 'Sid,' seeing an opportunity.
Aunt Sally firmly refuses, stating that one boy lost at a time is enough and that if 'Sid' isn't back by supper, Uncle Silas will go.
When 'Sid' (Tom Sawyer) fails to appear for supper, Uncle Silas departs to search for him.
Uncle Silas returns around ten o'clock, somewhat uneasy, as he couldn't find any trace of 'Tom's track' (referring to Tom Sawyer, currently known as 'Sid').
Aunt Sally becomes considerably more anxious, though Uncle Silas tries to reassure her by saying boys will be boys and 'Sid' will likely turn up in the morning.
Though somewhat pacified, Aunt Sally resolves to stay up for a while and keep a light burning for 'Sid.'
Later, when Huck goes to bed, Aunt Sally accompanies him, tucks him in, and shows him such motherly affection that Huck feels guilty and finds it hard to look at her.
She sits on his bed, talking at length about what a wonderful boy 'Sid' is, repeatedly asking Huck if he thinks 'Sid' could be lost, hurt, or even drowned, her tears falling silently.
Huck reassures her that 'Sid' is fine and will be home in the morning, and she asks him to repeat his assurances, finding comfort in them.

I see my chance; so I skips up and says:
“I’ll run right up to town and get him,” I says.
“No you won’t,” she says. “You’ll stay right wher’ you are; one’s enough to be lost at a time. If he ain’t here to supper, your uncle ’ll go.”
Well, he warn’t there to supper; so right after supper uncle went.
He come back about ten a little bit uneasy; hadn’t run across Tom’s track. Aunt Sally was a good deal uneasy; but Uncle Silas he said there warn’t no occasion to be—boys will be boys, he said, and you’ll see this one turn up in the morning all sound and right. So she had to be satisfied. But she said she’d set up for him a while anyway, and keep a light burning so he could see it.
And then when I went up to bed she come up with me and fetched her candle, and tucked me in, and mothered me so good I felt mean, and like I couldn’t look her in the face; and she set down on the bed and talked with me a long time, and said what a splendid boy Sid was, and didn’t seem to want to ever stop talking about him; and kept asking me every now and then if I reckoned he could a got lost, or hurt, or maybe drownded, and might be laying at this minute somewheres suffering or dead, and she not by him to help him, and so the tears would drip down silent, and I would tell her that Sid was all right, and would be home in the morning, sure; and she would squeeze my hand, or maybe kiss me, and tell me to say it again, and keep on saying it, because it done her good, and she was in so much trouble.

events.title: Aunt Sally's Plea, Huck's Internal Conflict, and a Night of Vigil
detailed_summary: As Aunt Sally is about to leave Huck's room, she looks at him gently and earnestly.
She tells 'Tom' (Huck) that the door will not be locked and mentions the window and lightning rod, then pleads with him to be good and not leave, for her sake.
Huck, who desperately wants to go check on the real Tom Sawyer and had fully intended to, feels he cannot leave after her heartfelt request, not even for 'kingdoms.'
His mind is troubled by thoughts of both Aunt Sally and Tom, leading to a restless night's sleep.
Twice during the night, he secretly climbs down the lightning rod and observes Aunt Sally still sitting by her candle in the window, her eyes fixed on the road, tears visible.
Huck wishes he could comfort her but feels helpless, only able to resolve never to cause her further grief.
Waking a third time at dawn, he slides down again to find her still there, asleep in her chair, her head resting on her hand, the candle almost extinguished.

And when she was going away she looked down in my eyes so steady and gentle, and says:
“The door ain’t going to be locked, Tom, and there’s the window and the rod; but you’ll be good, won’t you? And you won’t go? For my sake.”
Laws knows I wanted to go bad enough to see about Tom, and was all intending to go; but after that I wouldn’t a went, not for kingdoms.
But she was on my mind and Tom was on my mind, so I slept very restless. And twice I went down the rod away in the night, and slipped around front, and see her setting there by her candle in the window with her eyes towards the road and the tears in them; and I wished I could do something for her, but I couldn’t, only to swear that I wouldn’t never do nothing to grieve her any more. And the third time I waked up at dawn, and slid down, and she was there yet, and her candle was most out, and her old gray head was resting on her hand, and she was asleep.

events.title: Anxious Wait and Tom's Dramatic Return
detailed_summary: Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally are consumed with worry at the breakfast table, having not heard from Tom.
Uncle Silas remembers he received a letter from the post office the previous day.
Aunt Sally takes the letter and identifies it as being from her sister in St. Petersburg.

Before Aunt Sally can open the letter, a commotion interrupts them: Tom Sawyer arrives on a mattress, carried by several people, accompanied by the old doctor, and Jim, who is in Aunt Sally's calico dress with his hands tied.
Huck, witnessing the scene, quickly conceals the unopened letter.
Aunt Sally initially cries out in fear that Tom is dead.
Upon seeing Tom move his head and mutter, she is overcome with relief that he is alive, though clearly not lucid.
She kisses Tom and then hurries off to prepare a bed, shouting instructions to everyone around her.

The old man was uptown again before breakfast, but couldn’t get no track of Tom; and both of them set at the table thinking, and not saying nothing, and looking mournful, and their coffee getting cold, and not eating anything. And by-and-by the old man says:
“Did I give you the letter?”
“What letter?”
“The one I got yesterday out of the post-office.”
“No, you didn’t give me no letter.”
“Well, I must a forgot it.”
So he rummaged his pockets, and then went off somewheres where he had laid it down, and fetched it, and give it to her. She says:
“Why, it’s from St. Petersburg—it’s from Sis.”
I allowed another walk would do me good; but I couldn’t stir. But before she could break it open she dropped it and run—for she see something. And so did I. It was Tom Sawyer on a mattress; and that old doctor; and Jim, in her calico dress, with his hands tied behind him; and a lot of people. I hid the letter behind the first thing that come handy, and rushed. She flung herself at Tom, crying, and says:
“Oh, he’s dead, he’s dead, I know he’s dead!”
And Tom he turned his head a little, and muttered something or other, which showed he warn’t in his right mind; then she flung up her hands, and says:
“He’s alive, thank God! And that’s enough!” and she snatched a kiss of him, and flew for the house to get the bed ready, and scattering orders right and left at the niggers and everybody else, as fast as her tongue could go, every jump of the way.

But Tom he opened his eyes, and says:

events.title: Jim's Fate Debated by the Mob
detailed_summary: Huck trails the group of men who have captured Jim, while the doctor and Uncle Silas take Tom inside.
The men are agitated, and some suggest hanging Jim as a warning to other slaves to prevent future escape attempts and the trouble they cause.
Others in the crowd argue against hanging Jim, pointing out that he is not their property and his rightful owner would likely demand financial compensation from them.
The prospect of having to pay for Jim tempers the anger of the most vocal proponents of hanging, as they are typically unwilling to bear such costs.

events.title: Jim's Harsh Re-imprisonment and the Doctor's Defense
detailed_summary: Jim endures verbal abuse and some physical blows from the men but remains silent and does not acknowledge Huck.
He is confined to the same cabin as before, now dressed in his own clothes, and is more securely chained to a log, with his hands and both legs also bound.
The men declare that Jim will only receive bread and water until his owner claims him or he is sold at auction.
The escape hole Huck and Tom made is filled in, and a stricter guard routine is established, involving armed farmers at night and a bulldog during the day.
As the men are concluding their efforts, the old doctor arrives and addresses them.
The doctor urges the men not to be unnecessarily harsh with Jim, stating he is not a bad person.
He recounts how, upon finding Tom wounded, he realized he couldn't remove the bullet alone and Tom was too unwell to be left.
Jim, despite being a runaway, voluntarily came forward and provided excellent assistance in caring for Tom.

The doctor explains he was compelled to stay with Tom and Jim throughout the day and night, as he couldn't risk Jim escaping, and Jim proved to be a remarkably faithful and diligent nurse, even though it meant risking his own freedom and despite being clearly exhausted from recent hard work.
He emphasizes Jim's good character and considerable value, noting how Jim was eventually captured while asleep after his tiring vigil.
The doctor concludes by reiterating his positive assessment of Jim.

They cussed Jim considerble, though, and give him a cuff or two side the head once in a while, but Jim never said nothing, and he never let on to know me, and they took him to the same cabin, and put his own clothes on him, and chained him again, and not to no bed-leg this time, but to a big staple drove into the bottom log, and chained his hands, too, and both legs, and said he warn’t to have nothing but bread and water to eat after this till his owner come, or he was sold at auction because he didn’t come in a certain length of time, and filled up our hole, and said a couple of farmers with guns must stand watch around about the cabin every night, and a bulldog tied to the door in the daytime; and about this time they was through with the job and was tapering off with a kind of generl good-bye cussing, and then the old doctor comes and takes a look, and says:
“Don’t be no rougher on him than you’re obleeged to, because he ain’t a bad nigger. When I got to where I found the boy I see I couldn’t cut the bullet out without some help, and he warn’t in no condition for me to leave to go and get help; and he got a little worse and a little worse, and after a long time he went out of his head, and wouldn’t let me come a-nigh him any more, and said if I chalked his raft he’d kill me, and no end of wild foolishness like that, and I see I couldn’t do anything at all with him; so I says, I got to have help somehow; and the minute I says it out crawls this nigger from somewheres and says he’ll help, and he done it, too, and done it very well. Of course I judged he must be a runaway nigger, and there I was! and there I had to stick right straight along all the rest of the day and all night. It was a fix, I tell you! I had a couple of patients with the chills, and of course I’d of liked to run up to town and see them, but I dasn’t, because the nigger might get away, and then I’d be to blame; and yet never a skiff come close enough for me to hail. So there I had to stick plumb until daylight this morning; and I never see a nigger that was a better nuss or faithfuller, and yet he was risking his freedom to do it, and was all tired out, too, and I see plain enough he’d been worked main hard lately. I liked the nigger for that; I tell you, gentlemen, a nigger like that is worth a thousand dollars—and kind treatment, too. I had everything I needed, and the boy was doing as well there as he would a done at home—better, maybe, because it was so quiet; but there I was, with both of ’m on my hands, and there I had to stick till about dawn this morning; then some men in a skiff come by, and as good luck would have it the nigger was setting by the pallet with his head propped on his knees sound asleep; so I motioned them in quiet, and they slipped up on him and grabbed him and tied him before he knowed what he was about, and we never had no trouble. And the boy being in a kind of a flighty sleep, too, we muffled the oars and hitched the raft on, and towed her over very nice and quiet, and the nigger never made the least row nor said a word from the start. He ain’t no bad nigger, gentlemen; that’s what I think about him.”

They cussed Jim considerable, though, and give him a cuff or two side the head once in a while, but Jim never said nothing, and he never let on to know me, and they took him to the same cabin, and put his own clothes on him, and chained him again, and not to no bed-leg this time, but to a big staple drove into the bottom log, and chained his hands, too, and both legs, and said he warn’t to have nothing but bread and water to eat after this till his owner come, or he was sold at auction because he didn’t come in a certain length of time, and filled up our hole, and said a couple of farmers with guns must stand watch around about the cabin every night, and a bulldog tied to the door in the daytime; and about this time they was through with the job and was tapering off with a kind of general good-bye cussing, and then the old doctor comes and takes a look, and says:

"Don’t be no rougher on him than you’re obliged to, because he ain’t a bad nigger. When I got to where I found the boy, I see I couldn’t cut the bullet out without some help, and he warn’t in no condition for me to leave to go and get help; and he got a little worse and a little worse, and after a long time he went out of his head, and wouldn’t let me come a nigh him any more, and said if I chalked his raft he’d kill me, and no end of wild foolishness like that, and I see I couldn’t do anything at all with him; so I says, I got to have help somehow; and the minute I says it, out crawls this nigger from somewheres, and says he’ll help, and he done it, too, and done it very well. Of course, I judged he must be a runaway nigger, and there I was; and there I had to stick right straight along all the rest of the day, and all night. It was a fix, I tell you! I had a couple of patients with the chills, and of course I’d of liked to run up to town and see them, but I dasn’t, because the nigger might get away, and then I’d be to blame; and yet, never a skiff come close enough for me to hail. So there I had to stick, plumb until daylight this morning; and I never see a nigger that was a better nuss or faithfuller, and yet he was risking his freedom to do it, and was all tired out, too, and I do believe he cared just as much for his master’s son as if he’d been white. He was that kind of nigger. Yes, sir, old Jim is worth a thousand dollars—and kind treatment, too. I see him standing my watch on top of his’n, ’stead of sleeping, so I could get a rest; and I see how tired he was, and how the sweat run off of him, and how he’d tuck every single care of that boy, and how he’d done it all for me, and for the boy’s good, and not for no reward, because he risked his freedom to do it, and I never see a nigger that was more faithful. Well, when daylight come, the boy was doing better, and Jim was tuckered out and asleep, and I was just a-watching, when I see the men coming in a skiff, and I motioned them to be still and not make no noise. They muffled their oars, and come up slow and quiet, and when they got there, they just laid hold of Jim, and never let him make the least little noise, and towed the raft away, and the boy and me on it, and Jim never made the least resistance, but just laid there, and let them do what they wanted. And that’s the whole story, gentlemen. I don’t want to see him mistreated, and I think he deserves to be treated well for what he done."

events.title: Softened Attitudes and Huck's Anxieties
detailed_summary: A man in the crowd concedes that the doctor's account is compelling.
The other men also seem to soften their attitudes towards Jim, which greatly relieves Huck and confirms his initial good opinion of the doctor.
The group agrees that Jim behaved admirably and deserves acknowledgment, so they all promise to stop cursing him.
Despite these sentiments, Jim is locked up without any lessening of his heavy chains or improvement to his bread-and-water diet.
Huck wishes for better conditions for Jim but feels it is not his place to intervene directly.

He resolves to tell Aunt Sally about the doctor's account of Jim's help and simultaneously worries about the difficult explanations he will soon have to provide regarding his failure to mention "Sid's" gunshot wound when recounting their night adventure hunting for Jim.

events.title: Tom's Awakening and Grand Confession
detailed_summary: Huck notes that he has ample time to prepare his explanations, as Aunt Sally is constantly by Tom's side in the sick-room, and Huck manages to avoid encountering Uncle Silas.
The following morning, Huck learns Tom is significantly better and Aunt Sally has gone to take a nap.
He slips into the sick-room, hoping that if Tom is awake, they can devise a believable story for the family.
He finds Tom sleeping peacefully, his appearance much improved.
Aunt Sally quietly enters the room, motions for Huck to be still, and whispers her joy that Tom's symptoms are excellent and he appears to be recovering well.
They sit and watch Tom, who eventually stirs and opens his eyes, recognizing he is at home.
Tom immediately asks about the raft and then about Jim.
Huck confirms Jim is also there, though his tone is somewhat subdued, which Tom doesn't notice.
Tom, assuming their plan was a complete success, exclaims that they are all safe and asks Huck if he has told Aunt Sally about it.
When Aunt Sally inquires what Tom means, he proudly announces that he and "Sid" (Huck) were responsible for freeing Jim.
Aunt Sally is shocked and exclaims that Tom must be out of his head again.

Tom insists he is perfectly lucid and proceeds to give a lengthy, enthusiastic account of their entire elaborate scheme: the weeks of work, stealing supplies like candles and clothes, making tools and inscriptions, digging into the cabin, dealing with rats and snakes, and the final chaotic escape attempt where he was shot, culminating in his belief that Jim was now a free man thanks to their efforts.

But I had plenty time. Aunt Sally she stuck to the sick-room all day and all night, and every time I see Uncle Silas mooning around I dodged him.
Next morning I heard Tom was a good deal better, and they said Aunt Sally was gone to get a nap. So I slips to the sick-room, and if I found him awake I reckoned we could put up a yarn for the family that would wash. But he was sleeping, and sleeping very peaceful, too; and pale, not fire-faced the way he was when he come. So I set down and laid for him to wake. In about half an hour Aunt Sally comes gliding in, and there I was, up a stump again! She motioned me to be still, and set down by me, and begun to whisper, and said we could all be joyful now, because all the symptoms was first-rate, and he’d been sleeping like that for ever so long, and looking better and peacefuller all the time, and ten to one he’d wake up in his right mind.
So we set there watching, and by-and-by he stirs a bit, and opened his eyes very natural, and takes a look, and says:
“Hello!—why, I’m at home! How’s that? Where’s the raft?”
“It’s all right,” I says.
“And Jim?”
“The same,” I says, but couldn’t say it pretty brash. But he never noticed, but says:
“Good! Splendid! Now we’re all right and safe! Did you tell Aunty?”
I was going to say yes; but she chipped in and says: “About what, Sid?”
“Why, about the way the whole thing was done.”
“What whole thing?”
“Why, the whole thing. There ain’t but one; how we set the runaway nigger free—me and Tom.”
“Good land! Set the run— What is the child talking about! Dear, dear, out of his head again!”
“No, I ain’t out of my HEAD; I know all what I’m talking about. We did set him free—me and Tom. We laid out to do it, and we done it. And we done it elegant, too.” He’d got a start, and she never checked him up, just set and stared and stared, and let him clip along, and I see it warn’t no use for me to put in. “Why, Aunty, it cost us a power of work—weeks of it—hours and hours, every night, whilst you was all asleep. And we had to steal candles, and the sheet, and the shirt, and your dress, and spoons, and tin plates, and case-knives, and the warming-pan, and the grindstone, and flour, and just no end of things, and you can’t think what work it was to make the saws, and pens, and inscriptions, and one thing or another, and you can’t think half the fun it was. And we had to make up the pictures of coffins and things, and nonnamous letters from the robbers, and get up and down the lightning-rod, and dig the hole into the cabin, and made the rope ladder and send it in cooked up in a pie, and send in spoons and things to work with in your apron pocket—”
“Mercy sakes!”
“—and load up the cabin with rats and snakes and so on, for company for Jim; and then you kept Tom here so long with the butter in his hat that you come near spiling the whole business, because the men come before we was out of the cabin, and we had to rush, and they heard us and let drive at us, and I got my share, and we dodged out of the path and let them go by, and when the dogs come they warn’t interested in us, but went for the most noise, and we got our canoe, and made for the raft, and was all safe, and Jim was a free man, and we done it all by ourselves, and wasn’t it bully, Aunty!”

She went away again, but I stayed there by Tom till he woke up, and he looked kind of surprised, and says:

"Hello, Huck, have you been here all night?"

"No," I says, "I come in after Aunt Sally went out."

He says:

"What’s the talk, Huck?—I been a-dreaming."

"What about?"

"About the raft, and Jim. I reckon Jim is all right, now?"

"Yes," I says, kind of slow, "he’s here, and Aunt Sally’s been talking to him."

He never noticed how I said it, but he says:

"All right—that’s good. Now we’re all safe and sound again. Did you tell Aunt Sally about it, Huck?"

I says:

"Yes."

"What did she say?"

"She said she’d be hanged if she believed it."

He laughed, and says:

"She’s always that way. But say, Huck, what’s become of all the stuff we used to have in the cabin?"

"I don’t know," I says, "I ain’t seen it."

Just then Aunt Sally comes in, and Tom says:

"Aunt Sally, I’m all right, and Jim’s all right, and we done it all, and nobody ain’t hurt nor nothing."

Aunt Sally she grabbed him and hugged him, and says:

"Oh, Tom, you poor thing, you’re out of your head again!"

"No, I ain’t, Aunt Sally. It was all us—me and Sid. We done it."

"What did you do?"

"Why, we set Jim free!"

"Good gracious! Set who free?"

"Jim!"

She looked wild, and he says:

"Ain’t you heard nothing about it, Aunt Sally?"

"Heard what, child?"

"Why, about the whole thing. We planned it all out, and we worked at it weeks and weeks. We was bound to set him free, and we done it. And we had to steal candles, and sheets, and spoons, and tin plates, and beds, and shirts, and everything that was handy. And we made pens out of candlesticks, and wrote on the walls, and dug a tunnel, and let snakes and rats in, and baked a pie with a rope ladder in it, and sent it in to Jim, and all sorts of things. And at last, just as we was about to get away, I got shot; and here we are, and Jim’s free, and everything’s all right!"

But I had plenty time. Aunt Sally she stuck to the sick-room all day and all night, and every time I see Uncle Silas mooning around I dodged him. He seemed to be in a kind of daze, like he was always thinking about something he couldn’t quite get hold of, and I made sure to keep out of his way, for fear he’d start asking questions I couldn’t answer. Tom, he was laid up in bed, but he was always scheming, whispering to me when Aunt Sally wasn’t around, and making plans for how we was going to get Jim out of the shed.

The days dragged on, and I kept busy fetching things for Tom, and sneaking out to the shed to talk to Jim when I could. Jim, he was getting mighty anxious, but he kept his spirits up, saying he trusted us boys to get him out. I told him to keep quiet and not let on to anybody, and he said he wouldn’t, not for the world. Tom, he kept making up new ideas for the escape, each one wilder than the last. He wanted to dig a tunnel with case-knives, and make Jim write a journal on a shirt with his own blood, and all sorts of things. I told him it was all foolishness, but Tom said it wouldn’t be an adventure if we didn’t do it right.

One night, after Aunt Sally had gone to bed and the house was quiet, Tom and me slipped out with our tools. We crept through the yard, keeping to the shadows, and made our way to the shed where Jim was locked up. Tom had a plan to saw the leg off the bed so Jim could slip his chain, and I was to keep watch. We worked for hours, sawing and whispering, and finally got the chain loose. Jim was so grateful he nearly cried, but Tom said we wasn’t done yet. We had to bake a pie with a rope ladder in it, and smuggle it in to Jim, just like in the books.

The next day, I helped Aunt Sally in the kitchen, pretending to be as innocent as a lamb, while Tom sneaked around gathering things for the escape. He got a sheet for the ladder, and a spoon for digging, and even a candlestick to write with. Aunt Sally kept asking where things was going, and I had to make up stories to keep her from getting suspicious. It was hard work, but Tom said it was all part of the adventure.

At last, the night came when we was ready to make the final escape. Tom and me slipped out again, our hearts pounding, and made our way to the shed. We gave Jim the rope ladder and the pie, and he was so happy he hugged us both. We waited until the house was quiet, then slipped out into the night, making our way through the fields toward the river. But just as we was almost free, we heard a shout behind us. The men from the farm had found out Jim was gone, and they was after us with dogs and guns.

We ran as fast as we could, dodging through the trees and jumping over fences. Tom got caught on a branch and tore his pants, but we didn’t stop. Jim was running for his life, and I was right behind him, my heart beating fit to burst. At last, we made it to the river, and Jim jumped in the canoe we had hidden there. Tom and me scrambled in after him, and we pushed off into the darkness, the shouts of the men fading behind us.

We floated down the river, safe at last, and Jim was free. Tom was grinning from ear to ear, and I felt like I could fly. We had done it—we had set Jim free, and had the greatest adventure of our lives. I knew I’d never forget it, not as long as I lived.

events.title: Aunt Sally's Outrage and Tom's Shocking News about Jim
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally, finally grasping the full extent of their escapade, expresses her utter astonishment and calls them "little rapscallions" for causing widespread panic and distress.
She vows to punish them severely once Tom has recovered his health.
Tom, however, is too proud and joyful to be subdued and continues to revel in their perceived success, even as Aunt Sally interjects with fiery exasperation.
Aunt Sally warns Tom that he should not meddle with "the runaway nigger" again.
Tom, looking surprised, asks whom she is referring to.
When Aunt Sally clarifies she means Jim, Tom turns to Huck with a grave expression, questioning why Huck hadn't told him Jim was alright and had gotten away.

“Well, I never heard the likes of it in all my born days! So it was you, you little rapscallions, that’s been making all this trouble, and turned everybody’s wits clean inside out and scared us all most to death. I’ve as good a notion as ever I had in my life to take it out o’ you this very minute. To think, here I’ve been, night after night, a—you just get well once, you young scamp, and I lay I’ll tan the Old Harry out o’ both o’ ye!”
But Tom, he was so proud and joyful, he just couldn’t hold in, and his tongue just went it—she a-chipping in, and spitting fire all along, and both of them going it at once, like a cat convention; and she says:
“Well, you get all the enjoyment you can out of it now, for mind I tell you if I catch you meddling with him again—”
“Meddling with who?” Tom says, dropping his smile and looking surprised.
“With who? Why, the runaway nigger, of course. Who’d you reckon?”
Tom looks at me very grave, and says:
“Tom, didn’t you just tell me he was all right? Hasn’t he got away?”
“Him?” says Aunt Sally; “the runaway nigger? ’Deed he hasn’t. They’ve got him back, safe and sound, and he’s in that cabin again, on bread and water, and loaded down with chains, till he’s claimed or sold!”
Tom rose square up in bed, with his eye hot, and his nostrils opening and shutting like gills, and sings out to me:
“They hain’t no right to shut him up! Shove!—and don’t you lose a minute. Turn him loose! he ain’t no slave; he’s as free as any cretur that walks this earth!”

events.title: Jim's Legal Freedom Revealed and Aunt Polly's Surprise Arrival
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally, bewildered, asks what Tom means by his declaration of Jim's freedom.
Tom emphatically states that he means every word: Miss Watson passed away two months ago, and feeling remorseful for ever planning to sell Jim down the river, she had set him free in her will.

When Aunt Sally, still trying to process this, asks why on earth Tom would then go to all the trouble of orchestrating an escape for a man who was already free, Tom begins to explain that he wanted the adventure of it.
Before he can continue, Tom suddenly exclaims, "goodness alive, AUNT POLLY!"
Huck confirms that Aunt Polly is indeed standing right inside the doorway, looking unexpectedly pleasant and satisfied.

“What does the child mean?”

events.title: Identities Unraveled and Complex Motivations Clarified
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally reacts with overwhelming joy, rushing to embrace Aunt Polly and crying.
Huck, sensing the escalating tension and potential for awkward revelations, decides to hide under the bed.
After a moment, Aunt Polly disengages from the hug and looks sternly across at Tom.
When Aunt Sally refers to the boy in bed as "Sid," Aunt Polly immediately corrects her, stating that it is Tom, and then asks for Huck Finn.
Huck reluctantly emerges from his hiding place.

Aunt Sally is depicted as utterly baffled, a state shared by Uncle Silas when he is later informed of all the events, leaving him so disoriented that he preaches an unintelligible sermon that evening.
Tom's Aunt Polly proceeds to explain Huck's true identity and his circumstances.
Huck then explains that when Aunt Sally mistook him for Tom Sawyer, he felt compelled to maintain the charade, knowing Tom would relish the mystery and adventure of the situation.
He adds that Tom subsequently pretended to be Sid to make things easier for Huck.
Aunt Polly confirms Tom's earlier statement that old Miss Watson had indeed freed Jim in her will.

This revelation brings a moment of clarity for Huck, who finally understands how Tom, given his upbringing, could have participated in freeing a slave: Tom knew Jim was already legally free, thus turning the entire elaborate escape into a risk-free adventure for himself.

events.text_segment:
Aunt Sally jumped for her, and most hugged the head off of her, and cried over her, and I found a good enough place for me under the bed, for it was getting pretty sultry for us, seemed to me. And I peeped out, and in a little while Tom’s Aunt Polly shook herself loose and stood there looking across at Tom over her spectacles—kind of grinding him into the earth, you know. And then she says:
“Yes, you better turn y’r head away—I would if I was you, Tom.”
“Oh, deary me!” says Aunt Sally; “is he changed so? Why, that ain’t Tom, it’s Sid; Tom’s—Tom’s—why, where is Tom? He was here a minute ago.”
“You mean where’s Huck Finn—that’s what you mean! I reckon I hain’t raised such a scamp as my Tom all these years not to know him when I see him. That would be a pretty howdy-do. Come out from under that bed, Huck Finn.”
So I done it. But not feeling brash.
Aunt Sally she was one of the mixed-upest-looking persons I ever see—except one, and that was Uncle Silas, when he come in and they told it all to him. It kind of made him drunk, as you may say, and he didn’t know nothing at all the rest of the day, and preached a prayer-meeting sermon that night that gave him a rattling ruputation, because the oldest man in the world couldn’t a understood it. So Tom’s Aunt Polly, she told all about who I was, and what; and I had to up and tell how I was in such a tight place that when Mrs. Phelps took me for Tom Sawyer—she chipped in and says, “Oh, go on and call me Aunt Sally, I’m used to it now, and ’tain’t no need to change”—that when Aunt Sally took me for Tom Sawyer I had to stand it—there warn’t no other way, and I knowed he wouldn’t mind, because it would be nuts for him, being a mystery, and he’d make an adventure out of it, and be perfectly satisfied. And so it turned out, and he let on to be Sid, and made things as soft as he could for me.
And his Aunt Polly she said Tom was right about old Miss Watson setting Jim free in her will; and so, sure enough, Tom Sawyer had gone and took all that trouble and bother to set a free nigger free! and I couldn’t ever understand before, until that minute and that talk, how he could help a body set a nigger free with his bringing-up.

But Aunt Sally, she was just that glad to see her own child again, she never noticed me slipping away. I laid low under the bed, listening to the two of them talk and cry and laugh, and it made me feel kind of strange, like I was in the way of something too good for me to be part of. I could see their feet from where I was, and every now and then Aunt Sally would go to the door and call for Uncle Silas, and he’d come in, all flustered and happy, and then go out again to tell the hands or fetch something.

I was thinking maybe I’d just stay under there till things cooled off, but after a while, I got to feeling cramped and itchy, and I reckoned it was safe to crawl out. I dusted myself off and tried to look innocent, but Aunt Sally caught sight of me and said, “Why, Huck, where have you been all this time?”

I said, “Oh, just looking around, ma’am.”

She smiled at me, and I could see she was too happy to be bothered by anything. “Well, you come on and get some supper. You must be starving.”

So we all sat down to eat, and the table was full of good things—ham and greens and hot biscuits and honey, and Aunt Sally kept piling my plate high, like she was feeding a lost puppy. Tom, he was grinning from ear to ear, and telling stories about all the things he’d seen and done, and Aunt Sally and Uncle Silas just listened and shook their heads and laughed.

After supper, we all went out on the porch, and the sun was setting over the fields, turning everything gold and pink. The air was soft and warm, and the crickets were starting up. Aunt Sally sat in her rocking chair, with Tom on one side and me on the other, and she said, “I declare, I never thought I’d see this day. My own boy home again, and safe.”

Tom looked at her, and his eyes were shining. “I’m glad to be home, Aunt Sally. I surely am.”

And I sat there, feeling like maybe I belonged, just a little, and thinking that sometimes, things do turn out right, after all.

events.title: The Mystery of the Intercepted Letters
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly explains her unexpected arrival, stating that when she received Aunt Sally's letter announcing that "Tom and Sid" had arrived safely, she became suspicious, especially since she couldn't get clear answers from "Sid" (Huck, who was intercepting her mail to him) about the situation.
Aunt Sally interjects that she never received any such earlier letters from Aunt Polly.
Aunt Polly clarifies that she wrote twice to Aunt Sally to inquire what she meant by "Sid" being there.
Aunt Sally reiterates that she never received those letters.
Aunt Polly then turns slowly and severely towards Tom, demanding he hand over the letters.
Tom, with some irritation, admits that the letters are in his trunk, unopened, explaining he had kept them because he anticipated they would cause trouble and thought there was no hurry.
Aunt Polly remarks that Tom certainly deserves a punishment for his actions.
She also mentions sending another letter to inform them of her impending arrival.
Aunt Sally confirms she received that particular letter the previous day but admits she has not yet read it.
Huck considers offering a wager that Aunt Sally hasn't truly got the letter but decides it's safer to remain silent.

events.text_segment:
Well, Aunt Polly she said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had come all right and safe, she says to herself:
“Look at that, now! I might have expected it, letting him go off that way without anybody to watch him. So now I got to go and trapse all the way down the river, eleven hundred mile, and find out what that creetur’s up to this time; as long as I couldn’t seem to get any answer out of you about it.”
“Why, I never heard nothing from you,” says Aunt Sally.
“Well, I wonder! Why, I wrote you twice to ask you what you could mean by Sid being here.”
“Well, I never got ’em, Sis.”
Aunt Polly she turns around slow and severe, and says:
“You, Tom!”
“Well—what?” he says, kind of pettish.
“Don’t you what me, you impudent thing—hand out them letters.”
“What letters?”
“Them letters. I be bound, if I have to take aholt of you I’ll—”
“They’re in the trunk. There, now. And they’re just the same as they was when I got them out of the office. I hain’t looked into them, I hain’t touched them. But I knowed they’d make trouble, and I thought if you warn’t in no hurry, I’d—”
“Well, you do need skinning, there ain’t no mistake about it. And I wrote another one to tell you I was coming; and I s’pose he—”
“No, it come yesterday; I hain’t read it yet, but it’s all right, I’ve got that one.”
I wanted to offer to bet two dollars she hadn’t, but I reckoned maybe it was just as safe to not to. So I never said nothing.

events.title: Tom's Grandiose Post-Evasion Plan Revealed
detailed_summary: Huck inquires about Tom's original intentions for Jim's escape, considering Jim was already a free man.
Tom reveals an elaborate scheme he had conceived from the beginning.
The plan involved them accompanying Jim on the raft down to the river's mouth, enjoying adventures along the way.
Only at the end of this journey would they inform Jim of his freedom.
Following this revelation, they were to bring Jim back home in luxury on a steamboat.
Tom also intended to compensate Jim for his time spent as a captive.
The climax of Tom's plan was to be a grand, orchestrated welcome for Jim, featuring a torchlight procession and a brass band, which would establish Tom, Huck, and Jim as heroes.
Huck reflects that the way events actually transpired was probably just as satisfactory.

And he said, what he had planned in his head from the start, if we got Jim out all safe, was for us to run him down the river on the raft, and have adventures plumb to the mouth of the river, and then tell him about his being free, and take him back up home on a steamboat, in style, and pay him for his lost time, and write word ahead and get out all the niggers around, and have them waltz him into town with a torchlight procession and a brass-band, and then he would be a hero, and so would we. But I reckoned it was about as well the way it was.

events.title: Jim's Liberation, Recognition, and Fortuitous Reward
detailed_summary: Jim was quickly released from his chains.
Aunt Polly, Uncle Silas, and Aunt Sally showed great appreciation for Jim after learning how diligently he assisted the doctor in caring for Tom during his injury.
They treated Jim exceptionally well, providing him with ample food, leisure, and relieving him of any chores.
Jim was brought to Tom's sick-room where they engaged in a significant and uplifting conversation.
Tom presented Jim with forty dollars as compensation for his patient and commendable role as a prisoner during the elaborate, and ultimately unnecessary, escape plot.

Jim was immensely pleased by this monetary reward, exclaiming that his earlier premonition on Jackson's Island—about regaining wealth, which he believed was signified by his hairy chest—had now demonstrably come true.

events.title: Plans for New Adventures and Pap's Fate Revealed
detailed_summary: Tom, still in recovery, enthusiastically proposed that he, Huck, and Jim embark on a new series of adventures.

His plan was for the three of them to secretly depart one night, acquire the necessary gear, and spend a couple of weeks experiencing thrilling escapades among the Native American communities in the Territory.
Huck expressed his immediate agreement and enthusiasm for this new plan.

However, Huck then voiced a practical concern: he believed he lacked any money for the required outfit, assuming his absent father had returned, claimed his six thousand dollars from Judge Thatcher, and squandered it all on alcohol.
Tom corrected Huck, reassuring him that his substantial sum of money was still untouched and safe, and that Pap had not made an appearance since Huck's departure.
At this point, Jim interjected with a solemn and serious tone, informing Huck that his father would not be returning, ever.

When Huck pressed for an explanation for this definitive statement, Jim reminded him of the floating house they had encountered earlier on their river journey, which contained a deceased man covered by a blanket.

Jim then revealed the critical information he had withheld at the time: he had entered the house, uncovered the man, and deliberately prevented Huck from seeing the body, confirming now that the deceased individual was indeed Huck's father. This revelation meant Huck could finally access his inheritance.

“He ain’t a-comin’ back no mo’, Huck.”
I says:
“Why, Jim?”
“Nemmine why, Huck—but he ain’t comin’ back no mo.”

“Doan’ you ’member de house dat was float’n down de river, en dey wuz a man in dah, kivered up, en I went in en unkivered him and didn’ let you come in? Well, den, you kin git yo’ money when you wants it, kase dat wuz him.”

events.title: Huck's Farewell to Writing and Rejection of Civilization
detailed_summary: Tom is described as being almost fully recovered from his gunshot wound.
He now conspicuously wears the bullet that was extracted from his leg on a watch-guard around his neck, treating it as a memento and frequently consulting it as if it were a timepiece.
Huck declares that with these recent events resolved, there is nothing further of significance to narrate in his book.

He expresses immense relief at concluding his writing endeavor, admitting candidly that had he known beforehand the considerable trouble and effort involved in creating a book, he would never have embarked on the project and has no intention of ever undertaking such a task again.
Huck concludes his account by stating his firm intention to depart for the Territory ahead of the others.

His primary motivation for this preemptive departure is that Aunt Sally has plans to formally adopt him and attempt to "sivilize" him, an experience he finds unbearable and is determined to avoid, having endured it previously.
